preamble: We, the people of Kenya— ACKNOWLEDGING the supremacy of the Almighty God of all creation: HONOURING those who heroically struggled to bring freedom and justice to our land: PROUD of our ethnic, cultural and religious diversity, and determined to live in peace and unity as one indivisible sovereign nation: RESPECTFUL of the environment, which is our heritage, and determined to sustain it for the beneﬁt of future generations: COMMITTED to nurturing and protecting the well-being of the individual, the family, communities and the nation: RECOGNISING the aspirations of all Kenyans for a government based on the essential values of human rights, equality, freedom, democracy, social justice and the rule of law: EXERCISING our sovereign and inalienable right to determine the form of governance of our country and having participated fully in the making of this Constitution: ADOPT, ENACT and give this Constitution to ourselves and to our future generations. GOD BLESS KENYA

chapters.title: SOVEREIGNTY OF THE PEOPLE AND SUPREMACY OF THIS CONSTITUTION

clauses.text: All sovereign power belongs to the people of Kenya and shall be exercised only in accordance with this Constitution
The people may exercise their sovereign power either directly or through their democratically elected representatives
Sovereign power under this Constitution is delegated to the following State organs, which shall perform their functions in accordance with this Constitution—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: Parliament and the legislative assemblies in the county governments;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the national executive and the executive structures in the county governments; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the Judiciary and independent tribunals

clauses.text: The sovereign power of the people is exercised at—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the national level; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the county level. 1 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: This Constitution is the supreme law of the Republic and binds all persons and all State organs at both levels of government
No person may claim or exercise State authority except as authorised under this Constitution
The validity or legality of this Constitution is not subject to challenge by or before any court or other State organ
Any law, including customary law, that is inconsistent with this Constitution is void to the extent of the inconsistency, and any act or omission in contravention of this Constitution is invalid
The general rules of international law shall form part of the law of Kenya
Any treaty or convention ratiﬁed by Kenya shall form part of the law of Kenya under this Constitution
Every person has an obligation to respect, uphold and defend this Constitution
Any attempt to establish a government otherwise than in compliance with this Constitution is unlawful
Kenya is a sovereign Republic
The Republic of Kenya shall be a multi-party democratic State founded on the national values and principles of governance referred to in Article 10
Kenya consists of the territory and territorial waters comprising Kenya on the effective date, and any additional territory and territorial waters as deﬁned by an Act of Parliament
The territory of Kenya is divided into the counties speciﬁed in the First Schedule
The governments at the national and county levels are distinct and inter-dependent and shall conduct their mutual relations on the basis of consultation and cooperation
A national State organ shall ensure reasonable access to its services in all parts of the Republic, so far as it is appropriate to do so having regard to the nature of the service
The national language of the Republic is Kiswahili
The ofﬁcial languages of the Republic are Kiswahili and English
The State shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: promote and protect the diversity of language of the people of Kenya; and 2 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: promote the development and use of indigenous languages, Kenyan Sign language, Braille and other communication formats and technologies accessible to persons with disabilities

clauses.text: There shall be no State religion
The national symbols of the Republic are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the national ﬂag;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the national anthem;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the coat of arms; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the public seal

clauses.text: The national symbols are as set out in the Second Schedule
The national days are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: Madaraka Day, to be observed on 1st June;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: Mashujaa Day, to be observed on 20th October; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: Jamhuri Day, to be observed on 12th December

clauses.text: A national day shall be a public holiday
Parliament may enact legislation prescribing other public holidays, and providing for observance of public holidays

articles.title: National values and principles of governance

clauses.text: The national values and principles of governance in this Article bind all State organs, State ofﬁcers, public ofﬁcers and all persons whenever any of them—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: applies or interprets this Constitution;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: enacts, applies or interprets any law; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: makes or implements public policy decisions

clauses.text: The national values and principles of governance include—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: patriotism, national unity, sharing and devolution of power, the rule of law, democracy and participation of the people;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: human dignity, equity, social justice, inclusiveness, equality, human rights, non- discrimination and protection of the marginalised;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: good governance, integrity, transparency and accountability; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: sustainable development

clauses.text: This Constitution recognises culture as the foundation of the nation and as the cumulative civilization of the Kenyan people and nation. 3 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
The State shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: promote all forms of national and cultural expression through literature, the arts, traditional celebrations, science, communication, information, mass media, publications, libraries and other cultural heritage;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: recognise the role of science and indigenous technologies in the development of the nation; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: promote the intellectual property rights of the people of Kenya

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: ensure that communities receive compensation or royalties for the use of their cultures and cultural heritage; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: recognise and protect the ownership of indigenous seeds and plant varieties, their genetic and diverse characteristics and their use by the communities of Kenya

clauses.text: Every citizen is entitled to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the rights, privileges and beneﬁts of citizenship, subject to the limits provided or permitted by this Constitution; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a Kenyan passport and any document of registration or identiﬁcation issued by the State to citizens

clauses.text: A passport or other document referred to in clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may be denied, suspended or conﬁscated only in accordance with an Act of Parliament that satisﬁes the criteria referred to in Article 24

clauses.text: Every person who was a citizen immediately before the effective date retains the same citizenship status as of that date
Citizenship may be acquired by birth or registration
Citizenship is not lost through marriage or the dissolution of marriage
A person is a citizen by birth if on the day of the person’s birth, whether or not the person is born in Kenya, either the mother or father of the person is a citizen
Clause
applies equally to a person born before the effective date, whether or not the person was born in Kenya, if either the mother or father of the person is or was a citizen
Parliament may enact legislation limiting the effect of clauses
and
on the descendents of Kenyan citizens who are born outside Kenya
A child found in Kenya who is, or appears to be, less than eight years of age, and whose nationality and parents are not known, is presumed to be a citizen by birth

A person who is a Kenyan citizen by birth and who has ceased to be a Kenyan citizen because the person acquired citizenship of another country, is entitled on application to regain Kenyan citizenship. 4 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
A person who has been married to a citizen for a period of at least seven years is entitled on application to be registered as a citizen

A person who has been lawfully resident in Kenya for a continuous period of at least seven years, and who satisﬁes the conditions prescribed by an Act of Parliament, may apply to be registered as a citizen
A child who is not a citizen, but is adopted by a citizen, is entitled on application to be registered as a citizen
Parliament shall enact legislation establishing conditions on which citizenship may be granted to individuals who are citizens of other countries

This Article applies to a person as from the effective date, but any requirements that must be satisﬁed before the person is entitled to be registered as a citizen shall be regarded as having been satisﬁed irrespective of whether the person satisﬁed them before or after the effective date, or partially before, and partially after, the effective date
A citizen by birth does not lose citizenship by acquiring the citizenship of another country
If a person acquired citizenship by registration, the citizenship may be revoked if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the person acquired the citizenship by fraud, false representation or concealment of any material fact;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the person has, during any war in which Kenya was engaged, unlawfully traded or communicated with an enemy or been engaged in or associated with any business that was knowingly carried on in such a manner as to assist an enemy in that war;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the person has, within ﬁve years after registration, been convicted of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a term of three years or longer; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the person has, at any time after registration, been convicted of treason, or of an offence for which—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: a penalty of at least seven years imprisonment may be imposed; or (ii) a more severe penalty may be imposed

clauses.text: The citizenship of a person who was presumed to be a citizen by birth, as contemplated in Article 14
, may be revoked if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the citizenship was acquired by fraud, false representation or concealment of any material fact by any person;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the nationality or parentage of the person becomes known, and reveals that the person was a citizen of another country; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the age of the person becomes known, and reveals that the person was older than eight years when found in Kenya

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation— (a) prescribing procedures by which a person may become a citizen; 5 Constitution of Kenya Kenya (b) governing entry into and residence in Kenya; (c) providing for the status of permanent residents; (d) providing for voluntary renunciation of citizenship; (e) prescribing procedures for revocation of citizenship; (f) prescribing the duties and rights of citizens; and (g) generally giving effect to the provisions of this Chapter
The Bill of Rights is an integral part of Kenya’s democratic state and is the framework for social, economic and cultural policies

The purpose of recognising and protecting human rights and fundamental freedoms is to preserve the dignity of individuals and communities and to promote social justice and the realisation of the potential of all human beings
The rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: belong to each individual and are not granted by the State;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: do not exclude other rights and fundamental freedoms not in the Bill of Rights, but recognised or conferred by law, except to the extent that they are inconsistent with this Chapter; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: are subject only to the limitations contemplated in this Constitution

clauses.text: The Bill of Rights applies to all law and binds all State organs and all persons
Every person shall enjoy the rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights to the greatest extent consistent with the nature of the right or fundamental freedom
In applying a provision of the Bill of Rights, a court shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: develop the law to the extent that it does not give effect to a right or fundamental freedom; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: adopt the interpretation that most favours the enforcement of a right or fundamental freedom

clauses.text: In interpreting the Bill of Rights, a court, tribunal or other authority shall promote—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the values that underlie an open and democratic society based on human dignity, equality, equity and freedom; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the spirit, purport and objects of the Bill of Rights. 6 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: In applying any right under Article 43, if the State claims that it does not have the resources to implement the right, a court, tribunal or other authority shall be guided by the following principles —

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: it is the responsibility of the State to show that the resources are not available;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in allocating resources, the State shall give priority to ensuring the widest possible enjoyment of the right or fundamental freedom having regard to prevailing circumstances, including the vulnerability of particular groups or individuals; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the court, tribunal or other authority may not interfere with a decision by a State organ concerning the allocation of available resources, solely on the basis that it would have reached a different conclusion

articles.title: Implementation of rights and fundamental freedoms

clauses.text: It is a fundamental duty of the State and every State organ to observe, respect, protect, promote and fulﬁl the rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights
The State shall take legislative, policy and other measures, including the setting of standards, to achieve the progressive realisation of the rights guaranteed under Article 43

All State organs and all public ofﬁcers have the duty to address the needs of vulnerable groups within society, including women, older members of society, persons with disabilities, children, youth, members of minority or marginalised communities, and members of particular ethnic, religious or cultural communities
The State shall enact and implement legislation to fulﬁl its international obligations in respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms
Every person has the right to institute court proceedings claiming that a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights has been denied, violated or infringed, or is threatened
In addition to a person acting in their own interest, court proceedings under clause
may be instituted by—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a person acting on behalf of another person who cannot act in their own name;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a person acting as a member of, or in the interest of, a group or class of persons;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a person acting in the public interest; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: an association acting in the interest of one or more of its members

clauses.text: The Chief Justice shall make rules providing for the court proceedings referred to in this Article, which shall satisfy the criteria that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the rights of standing provided for in clause

clauses.text: are fully facilitated;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: formalities relating to the proceedings, including commencement of the proceedings, are kept to the minimum, and in particular that the court shall, if necessary, entertain proceedings on the basis of informal documentation;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: no fee may be charged for commencing the proceedings;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the court, while observing the rules of natural justice, shall not be unreasonably restricted by procedural technicalities; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: an organisation or individual with particular expertise may, with the leave of the court, appear as a friend of the court. 7 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The absence of rules contemplated in clause
does not limit the right of any person to commence court proceedings under this Article, and to have the matter heard and determined by a court

articles.title: Authority of courts to uphold and enforce the Bill of Rights

clauses.text: The High Court has jurisdiction, in accordance with Article 165, to hear and determine applications for redress of a denial, violation or infringement of, or threat to, a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights

Parliament shall enact legislation to give original jurisdiction in appropriate cases to subordinate courts to hear and determine applications for redress of a denial, violation or infringement of, or threat to, a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights
In any proceedings brought under Article 22, a court may grant appropriate relief, including—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a declaration of rights;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: an injunction;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a conservatory order;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: a declaration of invalidity of any law that denies, violates, infringes, or threatens a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights and is not justiﬁed under Article 24;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: an order for compensation; and

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: an order of judicial review

articles.title: Limitation of rights and fundamental freedoms

clauses.text: A right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights shall not be limited except by law, and then only to the extent that the limitation is reasonable and justiﬁable in an open and democratic society based on human dignity, equality and freedom, taking into account all relevant factors, including—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the nature of the right or fundamental freedom;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the importance of the purpose of the limitation;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the nature and extent of the limitation;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the need to ensure that the enjoyment of rights and fundamental freedoms by any individual does not prejudice the rights and fundamental freedoms of others; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the relation between the limitation and its purpose and whether there are less restrictive means to achieve the purpose

clauses.text: Despite clause
, a provision in legislation limiting a right or fundamental freedom—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: in the case of a provision enacted or amended on or after the effective date, is not valid unless the legislation speciﬁcally expresses the intention to limit that right or fundamental freedom, and the nature and extent of the limitation;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall not be construed as limiting the right or fundamental freedom unless the provision is clear and speciﬁc about the right or freedom to be limited and the nature and extent of the limitation; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: shall not limit the right or fundamental freedom so far as to derogate from its core or essential content

clauses.text: The State or a person seeking to justify a particular limitation shall demonstrate to the court, tribunal or other authority that the requirements of this Article have been satisﬁed. 8 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

The provisions of this Chapter on equality shall be qualiﬁed to the extent strictly necessary for the application of Muslim law before the Kadhis’ courts, to persons who profess the Muslim religion, in matters relating to personal status, marriage, divorce and inheritance
Despite clause
and
, a provision in legislation may limit the application of the rights or fundamental freedoms in the following provisions to persons serving in the Kenya Defence Forces or the National Police Service—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: Article 31 — Privacy;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: Article 36 — Freedom of association;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: Article 37 — Assembly, demonstration, picketing and petition;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: Article 41 — Labour relations;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: Article 43 — Economic and social rights; and

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: Article 49 — Rights of arrested persons

articles.title: Fundamental Rights and freedoms that may not be limited

clauses.text: Despite any other provision in this Constitution, the following rights and fundamental freedoms shall not be limited— (a) freedom from torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment; (b) freedom from slavery or servitude; (c) the right to a fair trial; and (d) the right to an order of habeas corpus. Part 2 – Rights and fundamental freedoms
Every person has the right to life
The life of a person begins at conception
A person shall not be deprived of life intentionally, except to the extent authorised by this Constitution or other written law

Abortion is not permitted unless, in the opinion of a trained health professional, there is need for emergency treatment, or the life or health of the mother is in danger, or if permitted by any other written law
Every person is equal before the law and has the right to equal protection and equal beneﬁt of the law
Equality includes the full and equal enjoyment of all rights and fundamental freedoms
Women and men have the right to equal treatment, including the right to equal opportunities in political, economic, cultural and social spheres

The State shall not discriminate directly or indirectly against any person on any ground, including race, sex, pregnancy, marital status, health status, ethnic or social origin, colour, age, disability, religion, conscience, belief, culture, dress, language or birth. 9 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
A person shall not discriminate directly or indirectly against another person on any of the grounds speciﬁed or contemplated in clause

To give full effect to the realisation of the rights guaranteed under this Article, the State shall take legislative and other measures, including afﬁrmative action programmes and policies designed to redress any disadvantage suffered by individuals or groups because of past discrimination
Any measure taken under clause
shall adequately provide for any beneﬁts to be on the basis of genuine need
In addition to the measures contemplated in clause
, the State shall take legislative and other measures to implement the principle that not more than two-thirds of the members of elective or appointive bodies shall be of the same gender
Every person has inherent dignity and the right to have that dignity respected and protected

articles.title: Freedom and security of the person

clauses.text: Every person has the right to freedom and security of the person, which includes the right not to be— (a) deprived of freedom arbitrarily or without just cause; (b) detained without trial, except during a state of emergency, in which case the detention is subject to Article 58; (c) subjected to any form of violence from either public or private sources; (d) subjected to torture in any manner, whether physical or psychological; (e) subjected to corporal punishment; or (f) treated or punished in a cruel, inhuman or degrading manner
A person shall not be held in slavery or servitude
A person shall not be required to perform forced labour

Every person has the right to privacy, which includes the right not to have— (a) their person, home or property searched; (b) their possessions seized; (c) information relating to their family or private affairs unnecessarily required or revealed; or (d) the privacy of their communications infringed

articles.title: Freedom of conscience, religion, belief and opinion

clauses.text: Every person has the right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion

Every person has the right, either individually or in community with others, in public or in private, to manifest any religion or belief through worship, practice, teaching or observance, including observance of a day of worship
A person may not be denied access to any institution, employment or facility, or the enjoyment of any right, because of the person’s belief or religion. 10 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
A person shall not be compelled to act, or engage in any act, that is contrary to the person’s belief or religion
Every person has the right to freedom of expression, which includes—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: freedom to seek, receive or impart information or ideas;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: freedom of artistic creativity; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: academic freedom and freedom of scientiﬁc research

clauses.text: The right to freedom of expression does not extend to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: propaganda for war;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: incitement to violence;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: hate speech; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: advocacy of hatred that—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: constitutes ethnic incitement, viliﬁcation of others or incitement to cause harm; or (ii) is based on any ground of discrimination speciﬁed or contemplated in Article 27

clauses.text: In the exercise of the right to freedom of expression, every person shall respect the rights and reputation of others
Freedom and independence of electronic, print and all other types of media is guaranteed, but does not extend to any expression speciﬁed in Article 33
The State shall not—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: exercise control over or interfere with any person engaged in broadcasting, the production or circulation of any publication or the dissemination of information by any medium; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: penalise any person for any opinion or view or the content of any broadcast, publication or dissemination

clauses.text: Broadcasting and other electronic media have freedom of establishment, subject only to licensing procedures that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: are necessary to regulate the airwaves and other forms of signal distribution; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: are independent of control by government, political interests or commercial interests

clauses.text: All State-owned media shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: be free to determine independently the editorial content of their broadcasts or other communications;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: be impartial; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: afford fair opportunity for the presentation of divergent views and dissenting opinions

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation that provides for the establishment of a body, which shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: be independent of control by government, political interests or commercial interests;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: reﬂect the interests of all sections of the society; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: set media standards and regulate and monitor compliance with those standards. 11 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: Every citizen has the right of access to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: information held by the State; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: information held by another person and required for the exercise or protection of any right or fundamental freedom

clauses.text: Every person has the right to the correction or deletion of untrue or misleading information that affects the person
The State shall publish and publicise any important information affecting the nation
Every person has the right to freedom of association, which includes the right to form, join or participate in the activities of an association of any kind
A person shall not be compelled to join an association of any kind
Any legislation that requires registration of an association of any kind shall provide that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: registration may not be withheld or withdrawn unreasonably; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: there shall be a right to have a fair hearing before a registration is cancelled

clauses.text: Every person has the right, peaceably and unarmed, to assemble, to demonstrate, to picket, and to present petitions to public authorities
Every citizen is free to make political choices, which includes the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to form, or participate in forming, a political party;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to participate in the activities of, or recruit members for, a political party; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to campaign for a political party or cause

clauses.text: Every citizen has the right to free, fair and regular elections based on universal suffrage and the free expression of the will of the electors for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: any elective public body or ofﬁce established under this Constitution; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any ofﬁce of any political party of which the citizen is a member

clauses.text: Every adult citizen has the right, without unreasonable restrictions—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to be registered as a voter;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to vote by secret ballot in any election or referendum; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to be a candidate for public ofﬁce, or ofﬁce within a political party of which the citizen is a member and, if elected, to hold ofﬁce

clauses.text: Every person has the right to freedom of movement
Every person has the right to leave Kenya. 12 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Every citizen has the right to enter, remain in and reside anywhere in Kenya
Subject to Article 65, every person has the right, either individually or in association with others, to acquire and own property—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: of any description; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in any part of Kenya

clauses.text: Parliament shall not enact a law that permits the State or any person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to arbitrarily deprive a person of property of any description or of any interest in, or right over, any property of any description; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to limit, or in any way restrict the enjoyment of any right under this Article on the basis of any of the grounds speciﬁed or contemplated in Article 27

clauses.text: The State shall not deprive a person of property of any description, or of any interest in, or right over, property of any description, unless the deprivation—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: results from an acquisition of land or an interest in land or a conversion of an interest in land, or title to land, in accordance with Chapter Five; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: is for a public purpose or in the public interest and is carried out in accordance with this Constitution and any Act of Parliament that—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: requires prompt payment in full, of just compensation to the person; and (ii) allows any person who has an interest in, or right over, that property a right of access to a court of law

clauses.text: Provision may be made for compensation to be paid to occupants in good faith of land acquired under clause
who may not hold title to the land
The State shall support, promote and protect the intellectual property rights of the people of Kenya
The rights under this Article do not extend to any property that has been found to have been unlawfully acquired
Every person has the right to fair labour practices
Every worker has the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to fair remuneration;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to reasonable working conditions;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to form, join or participate in the activities and programmes of a trade union; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to go on strike

clauses.text: Every employer has the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to form and join an employers' organisation; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to participate in the activities and programmes of an employers organisation

clauses.text: Every trade union and every employers’ organisation has the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to determine its own administration, programmes and activities;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to organise; and 13 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to form and join a federation

clauses.text: Every trade union, employers’ organisation and employer has the right to engage in collective bargaining

Every person has the right to a clean and healthy environment, which includes the right— (a) to have the environment protected for the beneﬁt of present and future generations through legislative and other measures, particularly those contemplated in Article 69; and (b) to have obligations relating to the environment fulﬁlled under Article 70
Every person has the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to the highest attainable standard of health, which includes the right to health care services, including reproductive health care;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to accessible and adequate housing, and to reasonable standards of sanitation;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to be free from hunger, and to have adequate food of acceptable quality;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to clean and safe water in adequate quantities;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to social security; and

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: to education

clauses.text: A person shall not be denied emergency medical treatment
The State shall provide appropriate social security to persons who are unable to support themselves and their dependants
Every person has the right to use the language, and to participate in the cultural life, of the person’s choice
A person belonging to a cultural or linguistic community has the right, with other members of that community—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to enjoy the person’s culture and use the person’s language; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to form, join and maintain cultural and linguistic associations and other organs of civil society

clauses.text: A person shall not compel another person to perform, observe or undergo any cultural practice or rite
The family is the natural and fundamental unit of society and the necessary basis of social order, and shall enjoy the recognition and protection of the State
Every adult has the right to marry a person of the opposite sex, based on the free consent of the parties
Parties to a marriage are entitled to equal rights at the time of the marriage, during the marriage and at the dissolution of the marriage. 14 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Parliament shall enact legislation that recognises—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: marriages concluded under any tradition, or system of religious, personal or family law; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any system of personal and family law under any tradition, or adhered to by persons professing a particular religion, to the extent that any such marriages or systems of law are consistent with this Constitution

clauses.text: Consumers have the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to goods and services of reasonable quality;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to the information necessary for them to gain full beneﬁt from goods and services;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to the protection of their health, safety, and economic interests; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to compensation for loss or injury arising from defects in goods or services

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for consumer protection and for fair, honest and decent advertising
This Article applies to goods and services offered by public entities or private persons
Every person has the right to administrative action that is expeditious, efﬁcient, lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair
If a right or fundamental freedom of a person has been or is likely to be adversely affected by administrative action, the person has the right to be given written reasons for the action
Parliament shall enact legislation to give effect to the rights in clause
and that legislation shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: provide for the review of administrative action by a court or, if appropriate, an independent and impartial tribunal; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: promote efﬁcient administration

clauses.text: The State shall ensure access to justice for all persons and, if any fee is required, it shall be reasonable and shall not impede access to justice
An arrested person has the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to be informed promptly, in a language that the person understands, of—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the reason for the arrest; (ii) the right to remain silent; and (iii) the consequences of not remaining silent;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to remain silent;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to communicate with an advocate, and other persons whose assistance is necessary;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: not to be compelled to make any confession or admission that could be used in evidence against the person; 15 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to be held separately from persons who are serving a sentence;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: to be brought before a court as soon as reasonably possible, but not later than—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: twenty-four hours after being arrested; or (ii) if the twenty-four hours ends outside ordinary court hours, or on a day that is not an ordinary court day, the end of the next court day;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: at the ﬁrst court appearance, to be charged or informed of the reason for the detention continuing, or to be released; and

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: to be released on bond or bail, on reasonable conditions, pending a charge or trial, unless there are compelling reasons not to be released

clauses.text: A person shall not be remanded in custody for an offence if the offence is punishable by a ﬁne only or by imprisonment for not more than six months

Every person has the right to have any dispute that can be resolved by the application of law decided in a fair and public hearing before a court or, if appropriate, another independent and impartial tribunal or body
Every accused person has the right to a fair trial, which includes the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to be presumed innocent until the contrary is proved;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to be informed of the charge, with sufﬁcient detail to answer it;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to have adequate time and facilities to prepare a defence;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to a public trial before a court established under this Constitution;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to have the trial begin and conclude without unreasonable delay;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: to be present when being tried, unless the conduct of the accused person makes it impossible for the trial to proceed;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: to choose, and be represented by, an advocate, and to be informed of this right promptly;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: to have an advocate assigned to the accused person by the State and at State expense, if substantial injustice would otherwise result, and to be informed of this right promptly;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: to remain silent, and not to testify during the proceedings;

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: to be informed in advance of the evidence the prosecution intends to rely on, and to have reasonable access to that evidence;

subClauses.label: k
subClauses.text: to adduce and challenge evidence;

subClauses.label: l
subClauses.text: to refuse to give self-incriminating evidence;

subClauses.label: m
subClauses.text: to have the assistance of an interpreter without payment if the accused person cannot understand the language used at the trial;

subClauses.label: n
subClauses.text: not to be convicted for an act or omission that at the time it was committed or omitted was not—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: an offence in Kenya; or (ii) a crime under international law;

subClauses.label: o
subClauses.text: not to be tried for an offence in respect of an act or omission for which the accused person has previously been either acquitted or convicted; 16 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: p
subClauses.text: to the beneﬁt of the least severe of the prescribed punishments for an offence, if the prescribed punishment for the offence has been changed between the time that the offence was committed and the time of sentencing; and

subClauses.label: q
subClauses.text: if convicted, to appeal to, or apply for review by, a higher court as prescribed by law

clauses.text: If this Article requires information to be given to a person, the information shall be given in a language that the person understands

Evidence obtained in a manner that violates any right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights shall be excluded if the admission of that evidence would render the trial unfair, or would otherwise be detrimental to the administration of justice
An accused person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: charged with an offence, other than an offence that the court may try by summary procedures, is entitled during the trial to a copy of the record of the proceedings of the trial on request; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: has the right to a copy of the record of the proceedings within a reasonable period after they are concluded, in return for a reasonable fee as prescribed by law

clauses.text: A person who is convicted of a criminal offence may petition the High Court for a new trial if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the person’s appeal, if any, has been dismissed by the highest court to which the person is entitled to appeal, or the person did not appeal within the time allowed for appeal; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: new and compelling evidence has become available

clauses.text: In the interest of justice, a court may allow an intermediary to assist a complainant or an accused person to communicate with the court

This Article does not prevent the exclusion of the press or other members of the public from any proceedings if the exclusion is necessary, in a free and democratic society, to protect witnesses or vulnerable persons, morality, public order or national security
Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the protection, rights and welfare of victims of offences

articles.title: Rights of persons detained, held in custody or imprisoned

clauses.text: A person who is detained, held in custody or imprisoned under the law, retains all the rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights, except to the extent that any particular right or a fundamental freedom is clearly incompatible with the fact that the person is detained, held in custody or imprisoned
A person who is detained or held in custody is entitled to petition for an order of habeas corpus
Parliament shall enact legislation that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: provides for the humane treatment of persons detained, held in custody or imprisoned; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: takes into account the relevant international human rights instruments. Part 3 – Speciﬁc application of rights

clauses.text: This Part elaborates certain rights to ensure greater certainty as to the application of those rights and fundamental freedoms to certain groups of persons
This Part shall not be construed as limiting or qualifying any right. 17 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Every child has the right—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to a name and nationality from birth;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to free and compulsory basic education;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to basic nutrition, shelter and health care;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to be protected from abuse, neglect, harmful cultural practices, all forms of violence, inhuman treatment and punishment, and hazardous or exploitative labour;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to parental care and protection, which includes equal responsibility of the mother and father to provide for the child, whether they are married to each other or not; and

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: not to be detained, except as a measure of last resort, and when detained, to be held—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: for the shortest appropriate period of time; and (ii) separate from adults and in conditions that take account of the child’s sex and age

clauses.text: A child’s best interests are of paramount importance in every matter concerning the child
A person with any disability is entitled—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to be treated with dignity and respect and to be addressed and referred to in a manner that is not demeaning;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to access educational institutions and facilities for persons with disabilities that are integrated into society to the extent compatible with the interests of the person;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to reasonable access to all places, public transport and information;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to use Sign language, Braille or other appropriate means of communication; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to access materials and devices to overcome constraints arising from the person’s disability

clauses.text: The State shall ensure the progressive implementation of the principle that at least ﬁve percent of the members of the public in elective and appointive bodies are persons with disabilities

The State shall take measures, including afﬁrmative action programmes, to ensure that the youth— (a) access relevant education and training; (b) have opportunities to associate, be represented and participate in political, social, economic and other spheres of life; (c) access employment; and (d) are protected from harmful cultural practices and exploitation

The State shall put in place afﬁrmative action programmes designed to ensure that minorities and marginalised groups— (a) participate and are represented in governance and other spheres of life; (b) are provided special opportunities in educational and economic ﬁelds; 18 Constitution of Kenya Kenya (c) are provided special opportunities for access to employment; (d) develop their cultural values, languages and practices; and (e) have reasonable access to water, health services and infrastructure

The State shall take measures to ensure the rights of older persons— (a) to fully participate in the affairs of society; (b) to pursue their personal development; (c) to live in dignity and respect and be free from abuse; and (d) to receive reasonable care and assistance from their family and the State. Part 4 – State of emergency
A state of emergency may be declared only under Article 132

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: and only when—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the State is threatened by war, invasion, general insurrection, disorder, natural disaster or other public emergency; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the declaration is necessary to meet the circumstances for which the emergency is declared

clauses.text: A declaration of a state of emergency, and any legislation enacted or other action taken in consequence of the declaration, shall be effective only—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: prospectively; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: for not longer than fourteen days from the date of the declaration, unless the National Assembly resolves to extend the declaration

clauses.text: The National Assembly may extend a declaration of a state of emergency—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: by resolution adopted—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: following a public debate in the National Assembly; and (ii) by the majorities speciﬁed in clause

clauses.text: ; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: for not longer than two months at a time

clauses.text: The ﬁrst extension of the declaration of a state of emergency requires a supporting vote of at least two-thirds of all the members of the National Assembly, and any subsequent extension requires a supporting vote of at least three-quarters of all the members of the National Assembly
The Supreme Court may decide on the validity of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a declaration of a state of emergency;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any extension of a declaration of a state of emergency; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: any legislation enacted, or other action taken, in consequence of a declaration of a state of emergency

clauses.text: Any legislation enacted in consequence of a declaration of a state of emergency—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: may limit a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights only to the extent that—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the limitation is strictly required by the emergency; and 19 Constitution of Kenya Kenya (ii) the legislation is consistent with the Republic’s obligations under international law applicable to a state of emergency; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall not take effect until it is published in the Gazette

clauses.text: A declaration of a state of emergency, or legislation enacted or other action taken in consequence of any declaration, may not permit or authorise the indemniﬁcation of the State, or of any person, in respect of any unlawful act or omission. Part 5 – Kenya National Human Rights and Equality Commission

articles.title: Kenya National Human Rights and Equality Commission

clauses.text: There is established the Kenya National Human Rights and Equality Commission
The functions of the Commission are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to promote respect for human rights and develop a culture of human rights in the Republic;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to promote gender equality and equity generally and to coordinate and facilitate gender mainstreaming in national development;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to promote the protection, and observance of human rights in public and private institutions;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to monitor, investigate and report on the observance of human rights in all spheres of life in the Republic, including observance by the national security organs;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to receive and investigate complaints about alleged abuses of human rights and take steps to secure appropriate redress where human rights have been violated;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: on its own initiative or on the basis of complaints, to investigate or research a matter in respect of human rights, and make recommendations to improve the functioning of State organs;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: to act as the principal organ of the State in ensuring compliance with obligations under treaties and conventions relating to human rights;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: to investigate any conduct in state affairs, or any act or omission in public administration in any sphere of government, that is alleged or suspected to be prejudicial or improper or to result in any impropriety or prejudice;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: to investigate complaints of abuse of power, unfair treatment, manifest injustice or unlawful, oppressive, unfair or unresponsive ofﬁcial conduct;

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: to report on complaints investigated under paragraphs

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: and take remedial action; and

subClauses.label: k
subClauses.text: to perform any other functions prescribed by legislation

clauses.text: Every person has the right to complain to the Commission, alleging that a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights has been denied, violated or infringed, or is threatened
Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to this Part, and any such legislation may restructure the Commission into two or more separate commissions
If Parliament enacts legislation restructuring the Commission under clause

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: that legislation shall assign each function of the Commission speciﬁed in this Article to one or the other of the successor commissions;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: each of the successor commissions shall have powers equivalent to the powers of the Commission under this Article; and 20 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: each successor commission shall be a commission within the meaning of

clauses.text: Land in Kenya shall be held, used and managed in a manner that is equitable, efﬁcient, productive and sustainable, and in accordance with the following principles—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: equitable access to land;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: security of land rights;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: sustainable and productive management of land resources;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: transparent and cost effective administration of land;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: sound conservation and protection of ecologically sensitive areas;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: elimination of gender discrimination in law, customs and practices related to land and property in land; and

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: encouragement of communities to settle land disputes through recognised local community initiatives consistent with this Constitution

clauses.text: These principles shall be implemented through a national land policy developed and reviewed regularly by the national government and through legislation
All land in Kenya belongs to the people of Kenya collectively as a nation, as communities and as individuals
Land in Kenya is classiﬁed as public, community or private
Public land is—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: land which at the effective date was unalienated government land as deﬁned by an Act of Parliament in force at the effective date;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: land lawfully held, used or occupied by any State organ, except any such land that is occupied by the State organ as lessee under a private lease;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: land transferred to the State by way of sale, reversion or surrender;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: land in respect of which no individual or community ownership can be established by any legal process;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: land in respect of which no heir can be identiﬁed by any legal process;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: all minerals and mineral oils as deﬁned by law;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: government forests other than forests to which Article 63

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: applies, government game reserves, water catchment areas, national parks, government animal sanctuaries, and specially protected areas; 21 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: all roads and thoroughfares provided for by an Act of Parliament;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: all rivers, lakes and other water bodies as deﬁned by an Act of Parliament;

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: the territorial sea, the exclusive economic zone and the sea bed;

subClauses.label: k
subClauses.text: the continental shelf;

subClauses.label: l
subClauses.text: all land between the high and low water marks;

subClauses.label: m
subClauses.text: any land not classiﬁed as private or community land under this Constitution; and

subClauses.label: n
subClauses.text: any other land declared to be public land by an Act of Parliament—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: in force at the effective date; or (ii) enacted after the effective date

clauses.text: Public land shall vest in and be held by a county government in trust for the people resident in the county, and shall be administered on their behalf by the National Land Commission, if it is classiﬁed under—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: clause

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: or

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: ; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , other than land held, used or occupied by a national State organ

clauses.text: Public land classiﬁed under clause

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: to

subClauses.label: m
subClauses.text: shall vest in and be held by the national government in trust for the people of Kenya and shall be administered on their behalf by the National Land Commission

clauses.text: Public land shall not be disposed of or otherwise used except in terms of an Act of Parliament specifying the nature and terms of that disposal or use
Community land shall vest in and be held by communities identiﬁed on the basis of ethnicity, culture or similar community of interest
Community land consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: land lawfully registered in the name of group representatives under the provisions of any law;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: land lawfully transferred to a speciﬁc community by any process of law;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: any other land declared to be community land by an Act of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: land that is—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: lawfully held, managed or used by speciﬁc communities as community forests, grazing areas or shrines; (ii) ancestral lands and lands traditionally occupied by hunter-gatherer communities; or (iii) lawfully held as trust land by the county governments, but not including any public land held in trust by the county government under Article 62

clauses.text: Any unregistered community land shall be held in trust by county governments on behalf of the communities for which it is held
Community land shall not be disposed of or otherwise used except in terms of legislation specifying the nature and extent of the rights of members of each community individually and collectively
Parliament shall enact legislation to give effect to this Article. 22 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

Private land consists of — (a) registered land held by any person under any freehold tenure; (b) land held by any person under leasehold tenure; and (c) any other land declared private land under an Act of Parliament
A person who is not a citizen may hold land on the basis of leasehold tenure only, and any such lease, however granted, shall not exceed ninety-nine years

If a provision of any agreement, deed, conveyance or document of whatever nature purports to confer on a person who is not a citizen an interest in land greater than a ninety-nine year lease, the provision shall be regarded as conferring on the person a ninety-nine year leasehold interest, and no more
For purposes of this Article—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a body corporate shall be regarded as a citizen only if the body corporate is wholly owned by one or more citizens; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: property held in trust shall be regarded as being held by a citizen only if all of the beneﬁcial interest of the trust is held by persons who are citizens

clauses.text: Parliament may enact legislation to make further provision for the operation of this Article

articles.title: Regulation of land use and property

clauses.text: The State may regulate the use of any land, or any interest in or right over any land, in the interest of defence, public safety, public order, public morality, public health, or land use planning
Parliament shall enact legislation ensuring that investments in property beneﬁt local communities and their economies
There is established the National Land Commission
The functions of the National Land Commission are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to manage public land on behalf of the national and county governments;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to recommend a national land policy to the national government;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to advise the national government on a comprehensive programme for the registration of title in land throughout Kenya;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to conduct research related to land and the use of natural resources, and make recommendations to appropriate authorities;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to initiate investigations, on its own initiative or on a complaint, into present or historical land injustices, and recommend appropriate redress;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: to encourage the application of traditional dispute resolution mechanisms in land conﬂicts;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: to assess tax on land and premiums on immovable property in any area designated by law; and 23 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: to monitor and have oversight responsibilities over land use planning throughout the country

clauses.text: The National Land Commission may perform any other functions prescribed by national legislation
; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: enact legislation—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: to prescribe minimum and maximum land holding acreages in respect of private land; (ii) to regulate the manner in which any land may be converted from one category to another; (iii) to regulate the recognition and protection of matrimonial property and in particular the matrimonial home during and on the termination of marriage; (iv) to protect, conserve and provide access to all public land;

subClauses.label: v
subClauses.text: to enable the review of all grants or dispositions of public land to establish their propriety or legality; (vi) to protect the dependants of deceased persons holding interests in any land, including the interests of spouses in actual occupation of land; and (vii) to provide for any other matter necessary to give effect to the provisions of this Chapter. Part 2 – Environment and natural resources

articles.title: Obligations in respect of the environment

clauses.text: The State shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: ensure sustainable exploitation, utilisation, management and conservation of the environment and natural resources, and ensure the equitable sharing of the accruing beneﬁts;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: work to achieve and maintain a tree cover of at least ten per cent of the land area of Kenya;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: protect and enhance intellectual property in, and indigenous knowledge of, biodiversity and the genetic resources of the communities;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: encourage public participation in the management, protection and conservation of the environment;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: protect genetic resources and biological diversity;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: establish systems of environmental impact assessment, environmental audit and monitoring of the environment;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: eliminate processes and activities that are likely to endanger the environment; and

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: utilise the environment and natural resources for the beneﬁt of the people of Kenya

clauses.text: Every person has a duty to cooperate with State organs and other persons to protect and conserve the environment and ensure ecologically sustainable development and use of natural resources. 24 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

If a person alleges that a right to a clean and healthy environment recognised and protected under Article 42 has been, is being or is likely to be, denied, violated, infringed or threatened, the person may apply to a court for redress in addition to any other legal remedies that are available in respect to the same matter
On application under clause
, the court may make any order, or give any directions, it considers appropriate—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to prevent, stop or discontinue any act or omission that is harmful to the environment;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to compel any public ofﬁcer to take measures to prevent or discontinue any act or omission that is harmful to the environment; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to provide compensation for any victim of a violation of the right to a clean and healthy environment

clauses.text: For the purposes of this Article, an applicant does not have to demonstrate that any person has incurred loss or suffered injury
A transaction is subject to ratiﬁcation by Parliament if it—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: involves the grant of a right or concession by or on behalf of any person, including the national government, to another person for the exploitation of any natural resource of Kenya; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: is entered into on or after the effective date

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the classes of transactions subject to ratiﬁcation under clause
Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to the provisions of this Part
Authority assigned to a State ofﬁcer—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is a public trust to be exercised in a manner that—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: is consistent with the purposes and objects of this Constitution; (ii) demonstrates respect for the people; (iii) brings honour to the nation and dignity to the ofﬁce; and (iv) promotes public conﬁdence in the integrity of the ofﬁce; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: vests in the State ofﬁcer the responsibility to serve the people, rather than the power to rule them. 25 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The guiding principles of leadership and integrity include—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: selection on the basis of personal integrity, competence and suitability, or election in free and fair elections;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: objectivity and impartiality in decision making, and in ensuring that decisions are not inﬂuenced by nepotism, favouritism, other improper motives or corrupt practices;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: selﬂess service based solely on the public interest, demonstrated by —

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: honesty in the execution of public duties; and (ii) the declaration of any personal interest that may conﬂict with public duties;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: accountability to the public for decisions and actions; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: discipline and commitment in service to the people

articles.title: Oath of ofﬁce of State ofﬁcers

clauses.text: Before assuming a State ofﬁce, acting in a State ofﬁce, or performing any functions of a State ofﬁce, a person shall take and subscribe to the oath or afﬁrmation of ofﬁce, in the manner and form prescribed by the Third Schedule or under an Act of Parliament
A State ofﬁcer shall behave, whether in public and ofﬁcial life, in private life, or in association with other persons, in a manner that avoids—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: any conﬂict between personal interests and public or ofﬁcial duties;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: compromising any public or ofﬁcial interest in favour of a personal interest; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: demeaning the ofﬁce the ofﬁcer holds

clauses.text: A person who contravenes clause
, or Article 76, 77 or 78

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: shall be subject to the applicable disciplinary procedure for the relevant ofﬁce; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may, in accordance with the disciplinary procedure referred to in paragraph

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: , be dismissed or otherwise removed from ofﬁce

clauses.text: A person who has been dismissed or otherwise removed from ofﬁce for a contravention of the provisions speciﬁed in clause
is disqualiﬁed from holding any other State ofﬁce
A gift or donation to a State ofﬁcer on a public or ofﬁcial occasion is a gift or donation to the Republic and shall be delivered to the State unless exempted under an Act of Parliament
A State ofﬁcer shall not—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: maintain a bank account outside Kenya except in accordance with an Act of Parliament; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: seek or accept a personal loan or beneﬁt in circumstances that compromise the integrity of the State ofﬁcer

articles.title: Restriction on activities of State ofﬁcers

clauses.text: A full-time State ofﬁcer shall not participate in any other gainful employment
Any appointed State ofﬁcer shall not hold ofﬁce in a political party. 26 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
A retired State ofﬁcer who is receiving a pension from public funds shall not hold more than two concurrent remunerative positions as chairperson, director or employee of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a company owned or controlled by the State; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a State organ

clauses.text: A retired State ofﬁcer shall not receive remuneration from public funds other than as contemplated in clause
A person is not eligible for election or appointment to a State ofﬁce unless the person is a citizen of Kenya
A State ofﬁcer or a member of the defence forces shall not hold dual citizenship
Clauses
and
do not apply to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: judges and members of commissions; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any person who has been made a citizen of another country by operation of that country’s law, without ability to opt out

articles.title: Legislation to establish the ethics and anti-corruption commission

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to establish an independent ethics and anti-corruption commission, which shall be and have the status and powers of a commission under

Parliament shall enact legislation— (a) establishing procedures and mechanisms for the effective administration of this Chapter; (b) prescribing the penalties, in addition to the penalties referred to in Article 75, that may be imposed for a contravention of this Chapter; (c) providing for the application of this Chapter, with the necessary modiﬁcations, to public ofﬁcers; and (d) making any other provision necessary for ensuring the promotion of the principles of leadership and integrity referred to in this Chapter, and the enforcement of this Chapter

articles.title: General principles for the electoral system

clauses.text: The electoral system shall comply with the following principles— (a) freedom of citizens to exercise their political rights under Article 38; (b) not more than two-thirds of the members of elective public bodies shall be of the same gender; (c) fair representation of persons with disabilities; 27 Constitution of Kenya Kenya (d) universal suffrage based on the aspiration for fair representation and equality of vote; and (e) free and fair elections, which are— (i) by secret ballot; (ii) free from violence, intimidation, improper inﬂuence or corruption; (iii) conducted by an independent body; (iv) transparent; and (v) administered in an impartial, neutral, efﬁcient, accurate and accountable manner
Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the delimitation by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission of electoral units for election of members of the National Assembly and county assemblies;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the nomination of candidates;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the continuous registration of citizens as voters;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the conduct of elections and referenda and the regulation and efﬁcient supervision of elections and referenda, including the nomination of candidates for elections; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the progressive registration of citizens residing outside Kenya, and the progressive realisation of their right to vote

clauses.text: Legislation required by clause

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: shall ensure that voting at every election is—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: simple;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: transparent; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: takes into account the special needs of—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: persons with disabilities; and (ii) other persons or groups with special needs

clauses.text: A person qualiﬁes for registration as a voter at elections or referenda if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is an adult citizen;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: is not declared to be of unsound mind; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: has not been convicted of an election offence during the preceding ﬁve years

clauses.text: A citizen who qualiﬁes for registration as a voter shall be registered at only one registration centre

Administrative arrangements for the registration of voters and the conduct of elections shall be designed to facilitate, and shall not deny, an eligible citizen the right to vote or stand for election

articles.title: Candidates for election and political parties to comply with code of conduct

clauses.text: In every election, all candidates and all political parties shall comply with the code of conduct prescribed by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission. 28 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

articles.title: Eligibility to stand as an independent candidate

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: or (ii), in the case of a candidate for election to the National Assembly or the Senate, respectively; or (ii) Article 193

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: (ii), in the case of a candidate for election to a county assembly

clauses.text: At every election, the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall ensure that— (a) whatever voting method is used, the system is simple, accurate, veriﬁable, secure, accountable and transparent; (b) the votes cast are counted, tabulated and the results announced promptly by the presiding ofﬁcer at each polling station; (c) the results from the polling stations are openly and accurately collated and promptly announced by the returning ofﬁcer; and (d) appropriate structures and mechanisms to eliminate electoral malpractice are put in place, including the safekeeping of election materials
Parliament shall enact legislation to establish mechanisms for timely settling of electoral disputes

Petitions concerning an election, other than a presidential election, shall be ﬁled within twenty- eight days after the declaration of the election results by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission
Service of a petition may be direct or by advertisement in a newspaper with national circulation. Part 2 – Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission and Delimitation of electoral units
There is established the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission
A person is not eligible for appointment as a member of the Commission if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: has, at any time within the preceding ﬁve years, held ofﬁce, or stood for election as—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: a member of Parliament or of a county assembly; or (ii) a member of the governing body of a political party; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: holds any State ofﬁce

clauses.text: A member of the Commission shall not hold another public ofﬁce. 29 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

The Commission is responsible for conducting or supervising referenda and elections to any elective body or ofﬁce established by this Constitution, and any other elections as prescribed by an Act of Parliament and, in particular, for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the continuous registration of citizens as voters;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the regular revision of the voters’ roll;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the delimitation of constituencies and wards;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the regulation of the process by which parties nominate candidates for elections;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the settlement of electoral disputes, including disputes relating to or arising from nominations but excluding election petitions and disputes subsequent to the declaration of election results;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: the registration of candidates for election;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: voter education;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: the facilitation of the observation, monitoring and evaluation of elections;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the regulation of the amount of money that may be spent by or on behalf of a candidate or party in respect of any election;

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: the development of a code of conduct for candidates and parties contesting elections; and

subClauses.label: k
subClauses.text: the monitoring of compliance with the legislation required by Article 82

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: relating to nomination of candidates by parties

clauses.text: The Commission shall exercise its powers and perform its functions in accordance with this Constitution and national legislation
There shall be two hundred and ninety constituencies for the purposes of the election of the members of the National Assembly provided for in Article 97

The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall review the names and boundaries of constituencies at intervals of not less than eight years, and not more than twelve years, but any review shall be completed at least twelve months before a general election of members of Parliament
The Commission shall review the number, names and boundaries of wards periodically
If a general election is to be held within twelve months after the completion of a review by the Commission, the new boundaries shall not take effect for purposes of that election

The boundaries of each constituency shall be such that the number of inhabitants in the constituency is, as nearly as possible, equal to the population quota, but the number of inhabitants of a constituency may be greater or lesser than the population quota in the manner speciﬁed in clause
to take account of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: geographical features and urban centres;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: community of interest, historical, economic and cultural ties; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: means of communication
