clauses.text: The number of inhabitants of a constituency or ward may be greater or lesser than the population quota by a margin of not more than—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: forty per cent for cities and sparsely populated areas; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: thirty per cent for the other areas. 30 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: In reviewing constituency and ward boundaries the Commission shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: consult all interested parties; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: progressively work towards ensuring that the number of inhabitants in each constituency and ward is, as nearly as possible, equal to the population quota

clauses.text: If necessary, the Commission shall alter the names and boundaries of constituencies, and the number, names and boundaries of wards
Subject to clauses
and

, the names and details of the boundaries of constituencies and wards determined by the Commission shall be published in the Gazette, and shall come into effect on the dissolution of Parliament ﬁrst following their publication
A person may apply to the High Court for review of a decision of the Commission made under this Article

An application for the review of a decision made under this Article shall be ﬁled within thirty days of the publication of the decision in the Gazette and shall be heard and determined within three months of the date on which it is ﬁled

For the purposes of this Article, "population quota" means the number obtained by dividing the number of inhabitants of Kenya by the number of constituencies or wards, as applicable, into which Kenya is divided under this Article
Elections for the seats in Parliament provided for under Articles 97

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: and 98

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: , and for the members of county assemblies under 177

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: , shall be on the basis of proportional representation by use of party lists

clauses.text: The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall be responsible for the conduct and supervision of elections for seats provided for under clause
and shall ensure that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: each political party participating in a general election nominates and submits a list of all the persons who would stand elected if the party were to be entitled to all the seats provided for under clause

clauses.text: , within the time prescribed by national legislation;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: except in the case of the seats provided for under Article 98

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , each party list comprises the appropriate number of qualiﬁed candidates and alternates between male and female candidates in the priority in which they are listed; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: except in the case of county assembly seats, each party list reﬂects the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya

clauses.text: The seats referred to in clause
shall be allocated to political parties in proportion to the total number of seats won by candidates of the political party at the general election. Part 3 – Political Parties
Every political party shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: have a national character as prescribed by an Act of Parliament;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: have a democratically elected governing body;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: promote and uphold national unity;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: abide by the democratic principles of good governance, promote and practise democracy through regular, fair and free elections within the party; 31 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: respect the right of all persons to participate in the political process, including minorities and marginalised groups;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: respect and promote human rights and fundamental freedoms, and gender equality and equity;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: promote the objects and principles of this Constitution and the rule of law; and

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: subscribe to and observe the code of conduct for political parties

clauses.text: A political party shall not—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: be founded on a religious, linguistic, racial, ethnic, gender or regional basis or seek to engage in advocacy of hatred on any such basis;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: engage in or encourage violence by, or intimidation of, its members, supporters, opponents or any other person;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: establish or maintain a paramilitary force, militia or similar organisation;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: engage in bribery or other forms of corruption; or

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: except as is provided under this

chapters.title: by an Act of Parliament, accept or use public

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for— (a) the reasonable and equitable allocation of airtime, by State-owned and other speciﬁed categories of broadcasting media, to political parties either generally or during election campaigns; (b) the regulation of freedom to broadcast in order to ensure fair election campaigning; (c) the regulation of political parties; (d) the roles and functions of political parties; (e) the registration and supervision of political parties; (f) the establishment and management of a political parties fund; (g) the accounts and audit of political parties; (h) restrictions on the use of public resources to promote the interests of political parties; and (i) any other matters necessary for the management of political parties
There is established a Parliament of Kenya, which shall consist of the National Assembly and the Senate
The National Assembly and the Senate shall perform their respective functions in accordance with this Constitution. 32 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
The legislative authority of the Republic is derived from the people and, at the national level, is vested in and exercised by Parliament
Parliament manifests the diversity of the nation, represents the will of the people, and exercises their sovereignty
Parliament may consider and pass amendments to this Constitution, and alter county boundaries as provided for in this Constitution
Parliament shall protect this Constitution and promote the democratic governance of the Republic
No person or body, other than Parliament, has the power to make provision having the force of law in Kenya except under authority conferred by this Constitution or by legislation
An Act of Parliament, or legislation of a county, that confers on any State organ, State ofﬁcer or person the authority to make provision having the force of law in Kenya, as contemplated in clause

, shall expressly specify the purpose and objectives for which that authority is conferred, the limits of the authority, the nature and scope of the law that may be made, and the principles and standards applicable to the law made under the authority
The National Assembly represents the people of the constituencies and special interests in the National Assembly
The National Assembly deliberates on and resolves issues of concern to the people
The National Assembly enacts legislation in accordance with Part 4 of this Chapter
The National Assembly—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: determines the allocation of national revenue between the levels of government, as provided in Part 4 of Chapter Twelve;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: appropriates funds for expenditure by the national government and other national State organs; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: exercises oversight over national revenue and its expenditure

clauses.text: The National Assembly—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: reviews the conduct in ofﬁce of the President, the Deputy President and other State ofﬁcers and initiates the process of removing them from ofﬁce; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: exercises oversight of State organs

clauses.text: The National Assembly approves declarations of war and extensions of states of emergency
The Senate represents the counties, and serves to protect the interests of the counties and their governments
The Senate participates in the law-making function of Parliament by considering, debating and approving Bills concerning counties, as provided in Articles 109 to 113
The Senate determines the allocation of national revenue among counties, as provided in Article 217, and exercises oversight over national revenue allocated to the county governments

The Senate participates in the oversight of State ofﬁcers by considering and determining any resolution to remove the President or Deputy President from ofﬁce in accordance with Article 145. 33 Constitution of Kenya Kenya Part 2 – Composition and membership of Parliament
The National Assembly consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: two hundred and ninety members, each elected by the registered voters of single member constituencies;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: forty-seven women, each elected by the registered voters of the counties, each county constituting a single member constituency;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: twelve members nominated by parliamentary political parties according to their proportion of members of the National Assembly in accordance with Article 90, to represent special interests including the youth, persons with disabilities and workers; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the Speaker, who is an ex ofﬁcio member

clauses.text: Nothing in this Article shall be construed as excluding any person from contesting an election under clause
The Senate consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: forty-seven members each elected by the registered voters of the counties, each county constituting a single member constituency;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: sixteen women members who shall be nominated by political parties according to their proportion of members of the Senate elected under paragraph

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: in accordance with Article 90;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: two members, being one man and one woman, representing the youth;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: two members, being one man and one woman, representing persons with disabilities; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the Speaker, who shall be an ex ofﬁcio member

clauses.text: The members referred to in paragraph

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: shall be elected in accordance with Article 90

clauses.text: Nothing in this Article shall be construed as excluding any person from contesting an election under clause

articles.title: Qualiﬁcations and disqualiﬁcations for election as member of Parliament

clauses.text: Unless disqualiﬁed under clause
, a person is eligible for election as a member of Parliament if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is registered as a voter;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: satisﬁes any educational, moral and ethical requirements prescribed by this Constitution or by an Act of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: is nominated by a political party, or is an independent candidate who is supported—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: in the case of election to the National Assembly, by at least one thousand registered voters in the constituency; or (ii) in the case of election to the Senate, by at least two thousand registered voters in the county. 34 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: A person is disqualiﬁed from being elected a member of Parliament if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is a State ofﬁcer or other public ofﬁcer, other than a member of Parliament;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: has, at any time within the ﬁve years immediately preceding the date of election, held ofﬁce as a member of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: has not been a citizen of Kenya for at least the ten years immediately preceding the date of election;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: is a member of a county assembly;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: is of unsound mind;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: is an undischarged bankrupt;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: is subject to a sentence of imprisonment of at least six months, as at the date of registration as a candidate, or at the date of election; or

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: is found, in accordance with any law, to have misused or abused a State ofﬁce or public ofﬁce or in any way to have contravened Chapter Six

clauses.text: A person is not disqualiﬁed under clause
unless all possibility of appeal or review of the relevant sentence or decision has been exhausted

articles.title: Promotion of representation of marginalised groups

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to promote the representation in Parliament of— (a) women; (b) persons with disabilities; (c) youth; (d) ethnic and other minorities; and (e) marginalised communities
A general election of members of Parliament shall be held on the second Tuesday in August in every ﬁfth year
Whenever a vacancy occurs in the ofﬁce of a member of the National Assembly under Article 97

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: , or of the Senate under Article 98

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: , the respective Speaker shall, within twenty- one days of the occurrence of the vacancy, give notice in writing of the vacancy to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the political party on whose party list the member was elected or nominated

clauses.text: A vacancy referred to in clause
shall, subject to clause
, be ﬁlled in the manner prescribed by an Act of Parliament within twenty-one days of the notiﬁcation by the respective Speaker
Whenever a vacancy occurs in the ofﬁce of a member of the National Assembly elected under Article 97

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , or of the Senate elected under Article 98

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the respective Speaker shall, within twenty-one days after the occurrence of the vacancy, give notice in writing of the vacancy to the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a by-election shall be held within ninety days of the occurrence of the vacancy, subject to clause

clauses.text: . 35 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
A vacancy referred to in clause
shall not be ﬁlled within the three months immediately before a general election
The term of each House of Parliament expires on the date of the next general election

When Kenya is at war, Parliament may, by resolution supported in each House by at least two-thirds of all the members of the House, from time to time extend the term of Parliament by not more than six months at a time
The term of Parliament shall not be extended under clause
for a total of more than twelve months

articles.title: Vacation of ofﬁce of member of Parliament

clauses.text: The ofﬁce of a member of Parliament becomes vacant—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: if the member dies;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: if, during any session of Parliament, the member is absent from eight sittings of the relevant House without permission, in writing, from the Speaker, and is unable to offer a satisfactory explanation for the absence to the relevant committee;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: if the member is otherwise removed from ofﬁce under this Constitution or legislation enacted under Article 80;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: if the member resigns from Parliament in writing to the Speaker;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: if, having been elected to Parliament—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: as a member of a political party, the member resigns from that party or is deemed to have resigned from the party as determined in accordance with the legislation contemplated in clause

clauses.text: ; or (ii) as an independent candidate, the member joins a political party;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: at the end of the term of the relevant House; or

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: if the member becomes disqualiﬁed for election to Parliament under Article 99

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the circumstances under which a member of a political party shall be deemed, for the purposes of clause

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: , to have resigned from the party

clauses.text: The electorate under Articles 97 and 98 have the right to recall the member of Parliament representing their constituency before the end of the term of the relevant House of Parliament
Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for the grounds on which a member may be recalled and the procedure to be followed
The High Court shall hear and determine any question whether—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a person has been validly elected as a member of Parliament; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the seat of a member has become vacant

clauses.text: A question under clause
shall be heard and determined within six months of the date of lodging the petition. 36 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to this Article. Part 3 – Ofﬁces of Parliament

articles.title: Speakers and Deputy Speakers of Parliament

clauses.text: There shall be—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a Speaker for each House of Parliament, who shall be elected by that House in accordance with the Standing Orders, from among persons who are qualiﬁed to be elected as members of Parliament but are not such members; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a Deputy Speaker for each House of Parliament, who shall be elected by that House in accordance with the Standing Orders, from among the members of that House

clauses.text: The ofﬁce of Speaker or Deputy Speaker shall become vacant—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: when a new House of Parliament ﬁrst meets after an election;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: if the ofﬁce holder, as a member of the relevant House, vacates ofﬁce under Article 103;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: if the relevant House so resolves by resolution supported by the votes of at least two-thirds of its members; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: if the ofﬁce holder resigns from ofﬁce in a letter addressed to the relevant House

clauses.text: At any sitting of a House of Parliament—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker presides;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in the absence of the Speaker, the Deputy Speaker presides; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: in the absence of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, another member of the House elected by the House presides

clauses.text: At a joint sitting of the Houses of Parliament, the Speaker of the National Assembly shall preside, assisted by the Speaker of the Senate
There shall be a leader of the majority party and a leader of the minority party
The leader of the majority party shall be the person who is the leader in the National Assembly of the largest party or coalition of parties
The leader of the minority party shall be the person who is the leader in the National Assembly of the second largest party or coalition of parties
The following order of precedence shall be observed in the National Assembly—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker of the National Assembly;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the leader of the majority party; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the leader of the minority party. 37 Constitution of Kenya Kenya Part 4 – Procedures for enacting Legislation

clauses.text: Parliament shall exercise its legislative power through Bills passed by Parliament and assented to by the President
Any Bill may originate in the National Assembly
A Bill not concerning county government is considered only in the National Assembly, and passed in accordance with Article 122 and the Standing Orders of the Assembly

A Bill concerning county government may originate in the National Assembly or the Senate, and is passed in accordance with Articles 110 to 113, Articles 122 and 123 and the Standing Orders of the Houses
A Bill may be introduced by any member or committee of the relevant House of Parliament, but a money Bill may be introduced only in the National Assembly in accordance with Article 114
In this Constitution, "a Bill concerning county government" means—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a Bill containing provisions affecting the functions and powers of the county governments set out in the Fourth Schedule;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a Bill relating to the election of members of a county assembly or a county executive; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a Bill referred to in Chapter Twelve affecting the ﬁnances of county governments

clauses.text: A Bill concerning county governments is—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a special Bill, which shall be considered under Article 111, if it—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: relates to the election of members of a county assembly or a county executive; or (ii) is the annual County Allocation of Revenue Bill referred to in Article 218; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: an ordinary Bill, which shall be considered under Article 112, in any other case

clauses.text: Before either House considers a Bill, the Speakers of the National Assembly and Senate shall jointly resolve any question as to whether it is a Bill concerning counties and, if it is, whether it is a special or an ordinary Bill
When any Bill concerning county government has been passed by one House of Parliament, the Speaker of that House shall refer it to the Speaker of the other House
If both Houses pass the Bill in the same form, the Speaker of the House in which the Bill originated shall, within seven days, refer the Bill to the President for assent
A special Bill concerning a county government shall proceed in the same manner as an ordinary Bill concerning county government, subject to clauses
and
The National Assembly may amend or veto a special Bill that has been passed by the Senate only by a resolution supported by at least two-thirds of the members of the Assembly

If a resolution in the National Assembly to amend or veto a special Bill fails to pass, the Speaker of the Assembly shall, within seven days, refer the Bill, in the form adopted by the Senate, to the President for assent. 38 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
If one House passes an ordinary Bill concerning counties, and the second House—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: rejects the Bill, it shall be referred to a mediation committee appointed under Article 113; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: passes the Bill in an amended form, it shall be referred back to the originating House for reconsideration

clauses.text: If, after the originating House has reconsidered a Bill referred back to it under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , that House—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: passes the Bill as amended, the Speaker of that House shall refer the Bill to the President within seven days for assent; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: rejects the Bill as amended, the Bill shall be referred to a mediation committee under Article 113

clauses.text: If a Bill is referred to a mediation committee under Article 112, the Speakers of both Houses shall appoint a mediation committee consisting of equal numbers of members of each House to attempt to develop a version of the Bill that both Houses will pass
If the mediation committee agrees on a version of the Bill, each House shall vote to approve or reject that version of the Bill
If both Houses approve the version of the Bill proposed by the mediation committee, the Speaker of the National Assembly shall refer the Bill to the President within seven days for assent
If the mediation committee fails to agree on a version of the Bill within thirty days, or if a version proposed by the committee is rejected by either House, the Bill is defeated
A money Bill may not deal with any matter other than those listed in the deﬁnition of "a money Bill" in clause

If, in the opinion of the Speaker of the National Assembly, a motion makes provision for a matter listed in the deﬁnition of "a money Bill", the Assembly may proceed only in accordance with the recommendation of the relevant Committee of the Assembly after taking into account the views of the Cabinet Secretary responsible for ﬁnance
In this Constitution, "a money Bill" means a Bill, other than a Bill speciﬁed in Article 218, that contains provisions dealing with—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: taxes;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the imposition of charges on a public fund or the variation or repeal of any of those charges;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the appropriation, receipt, custody, investment or issue of public money;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the raising or guaranteeing of any loan or its repayment; or

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: matters incidental to any of those matters

clauses.text: In clause
, "tax", "public money", and "loan" do not include any tax, public money or loan raised by a county. 39 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Within fourteen days after receipt of a Bill, the President shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: assent to the Bill; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: refer the Bill back to Parliament for reconsideration by Parliament, noting any reservations that the President has concerning the Bill

clauses.text: If the President refers a Bill back for reconsideration, Parliament may, following the appropriate procedures under this Part—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: amend the Bill in light of the President’s reservations; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: pass the Bill a second time without amendment

clauses.text: If Parliament amends the Bill fully accommodating the President’s reservations, the appropriate Speaker shall re-submit it to the President for assent

Parliament, after considering the President’s reservations, may pass the Bill a second time, without amendment, or with amendments that do not fully accommodate the President’s reservations, by a vote supported—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: by two-thirds of members of the National Assembly; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: two-thirds of the delegations in the Senate, if it is a Bill that requires the approval of the Senate

clauses.text: If Parliament has passed a Bill under clause

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the appropriate Speaker shall within seven days re-submit it to the President; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the President shall within seven days assent to the Bill

clauses.text: If the President does not assent to a Bill or refer it back within the period prescribed in clause
, or assent to it under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , the Bill shall be taken to have been assented to on the expiry of that period

clauses.text: A Bill passed by Parliament and assented to by the President shall be published in the Gazette as an Act of Parliament within seven days after-assent
Subject to clause
, an Act of Parliament comes into force on the fourteenth day after its publication in the Gazette, unless the Act stipulates a different date on or time at which it will come into force
An Act of Parliament that confers a direct pecuniary interest on members of Parliament shall not come into force until after the next general election of members of Parliament
Clause
does not apply to an interest that members of Parliament have as members of the public. Part 5 – Parliament's General Procedures and Rules
There shall be freedom of speech and debate in Parliament

Parliament may, for the purpose of the orderly and effective discharge of the business of Parliament, provide for the powers, privileges and immunities of Parliament, its committees, the leader of the majority party, the leader of the minority party, the chairpersons of committees and members. 40 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Parliament shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: conduct its business in an open manner, and its sittings and those of its committees shall be in public; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: facilitate public participation and involvement in the legislative and other business of Parliament and its committees

clauses.text: Parliament may not exclude the public, or any media, from any sitting unless in exceptional circumstances the relevant Speaker has determined that there are justiﬁable reasons for the exclusion
Every person has a right to petition Parliament to consider any matter within its authority, including to enact, amend or repeal any legislation
Parliament shall make provision for the procedure for the exercise of this right
The ofﬁcial languages of Parliament shall be Kiswahili, English and Kenyan Sign language, and the business of Parliament may be conducted in English, Kiswahili and Kenyan Sign language
In case of a conﬂict between different language versions of an Act of Parliament, the version signed by the President shall prevail
The quorum of Parliament shall be– (a) ﬁfty members, in the case of the National Assembly; or (b) ﬁfteen members, in the case of the Senate
Except as otherwise provided in this Constitution, any question proposed for decision in either House of Parliament shall be determined by a majority of the members in that House, present and voting
On a question proposed for decision in either House—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker has no vote; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in the case of a tie, the question is lost

clauses.text: A member shall not vote on any question in which the member has a pecuniary interest
In reckoning the number of members of a House of Parliament for any purpose of voting in that House, the Speaker of that House shall not be counted as a member
On election, all the members of the Senate who were registered as voters in a particular county shall collectively constitute a single delegation for purposes of clause
and the member elected under Article 98

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: shall be the head of the delegation. 41 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: When the Senate is to vote on any matter other than a Bill, the Speaker shall rule on whether the matter affects or does not affect counties
When the Senate votes on a matter that does not affect counties, each senator has one vote
Except as provided otherwise in this Constitution, in any matter in the Senate affecting counties—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: each county delegation shall have one vote to be cast on behalf of the county by the head of the county delegation or, in the absence of the head of the delegation, by another member of the delegation designated by the head of the delegation;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the person who votes on behalf of a delegation shall determine whether or not to vote in support of, or against, the matter, after consulting the other members of the delegation; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the matter is carried only if it is supported by a majority of all the delegations

clauses.text: Each House of Parliament may establish committees, and shall make Standing Orders for the orderly conduct of its proceedings, including the proceedings of its committees
Parliament may establish joint committees consisting of members of both Houses and may jointly regulate the procedure of those committees
The proceedings of either House are not invalid just because of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a vacancy in its membership; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the presence or participation of any person not entitled to be present at, or to participate in, the proceedings of the House

clauses.text: When a House of Parliament considers any appointment for which its approval is required under this Constitution or an Act of Parliament—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the appointment shall be considered by a committee of the relevant House;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the committee’s recommendation shall be tabled in the House for approval; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the proceedings of the committee and the House shall be in public

clauses.text: Either House of Parliament, and any of its committees, has power to summon any person to appear before it for the purpose of giving evidence or providing information
For the purposes of clause
, a House of Parliament and any of its committees has the same powers as the High Court—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to enforce the attendance of witnesses and examine them on oath, afﬁrmation or otherwise;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to compel the production of documents; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to issue a commission or request to examine witnesses abroad. Part 6 – Miscellaneous

clauses.text: A sitting of either House may be held at any place within Kenya and may commence at any time that the House appoints. 42 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

Whenever a new House is elected, the President, by notice in the Gazette, shall appoint the place and date for the ﬁrst sitting of the new House, which shall be not more than thirty days after the election
There is established the Parliamentary Service Commission
The Commission consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker of the National Assembly, as chairperson;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a vice-chairperson elected by the Commission from the members appointed under paragraph

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: seven members appointed by Parliament from among its members of whom—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: four shall be nominated equally from both Houses by the party or coalition of parties forming the national government, of whom at least two shall be women; and (ii) three shall be nominated by the parties not forming the national government, at least one of whom shall be nominated from each House and at least one of whom shall be a woman; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: one man and one woman appointed by Parliament from among persons who are experienced in public affairs, but are not members of Parliament

clauses.text: The Clerk of the Senate shall be the Secretary to the Commission
A member of the Commission shall vacate ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: if the person is a member of Parliament—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: at the end of the term of the House of which the person is a member; or (ii) if the person ceases to be a member of Parliament; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: if the person is an appointed member, on revocation of the person’s appointment by Parliament

clauses.text: Despite clause
, when the term of a House of Parliament ends, a member of the Commission appointed under clause

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: shall continue in ofﬁce until a new member has been appointed in the member’s place by the next House

clauses.text: The Commission is responsible for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: providing services and facilities to ensure the efﬁcient and effective functioning of Parliament;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: constituting ofﬁces in the parliamentary service, and appointing and supervising ofﬁce holders;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: preparing annual estimates of expenditure of the parliamentary service and submitting them to the National Assembly for approval, and exercising budgetary control over the service;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: undertaking, singly or jointly with other relevant organisations, programmes to promote the ideals of parliamentary democracy; and 43 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: performing other functions—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: necessary for the well-being of the members and staff of Parliament; or (ii) prescribed by national legislation

clauses.text: There shall be a Clerk for each House of Parliament, appointed by the Parliamentary Service Commission with the approval of the relevant House
The ofﬁces of the Clerks and ofﬁces of members of the staff of the Clerks shall be ofﬁces in the Parliamentary Service
Executive authority derives from the people of Kenya and shall be exercised in accordance with this Constitution
Executive authority shall be exercised in a manner compatible with the principle of service to the people of Kenya, and for their well-being and beneﬁt
The national executive of the Republic comprises the President, the Deputy President and the rest of the Cabinet
The composition of the national executive shall reﬂect the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya. Part 2 – The President and Deputy President
The President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is the Head of State and Government;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: exercises the executive authority of the Republic, with the assistance of the Deputy President and Cabinet Secretaries;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: is the Commander-in-Chief of the Kenya Defence Forces;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: is the chairperson of the National Security Council; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: is a symbol of national unity

clauses.text: The President shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: respect, uphold and safeguard this Constitution;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: safeguard the sovereignty of the Republic;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: promote and enhance the unity of the nation; 44 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: promote respect for the diversity of the people and communities of Kenya; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: ensure the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms and the rule of law

clauses.text: The President shall not hold any other State or public ofﬁce
The President shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: address the opening of each newly elected Parliament;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: address a special sitting of Parliament once every year and may address Parliament at any other time; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: once every year—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: report, in an address to the nation, on all the measures taken and the progress achieved in the realisation of the national values, referred to in Article 10; (ii) publish in the Gazette the details of the measures and progress under sub-paragraph

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: ; and (iii) submit a report for debate to the National Assembly on the progress made in fulﬁlling the international obligations of the Republic

clauses.text: The President shall nominate and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appoint, and may dismiss—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Cabinet Secretaries, in accordance with Article 152;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Attorney-General, in accordance with Article 156;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the Secretary to the Cabinet in accordance with Article 154;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: Principal Secretaries in accordance with Article 155;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: high commissioners, ambassadors and diplomatic and consular representatives; and

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: in accordance with this Constitution, any other State or public ofﬁcer whom this Constitution requires or empowers the President to appoint or dismiss

clauses.text: The President shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: chair Cabinet meetings;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: direct and co-ordinate the functions of ministries and government departments; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: by a decision published in the Gazette, assign responsibility for the implementation and administration of any Act of Parliament to a Cabinet Secretary, to the extent not inconsistent with any Act of Parliament

clauses.text: The President may—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: perform any other executive function provided for in this Constitution or in national legislation and, except as otherwise provided for in this Constitution, may establish an ofﬁce in the public service in accordance with the recommendation of the Public Service Commission;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: receive foreign diplomatic and consular representatives;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: confer honours in the name of the people and the Republic;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: subject to Article 58, declare a state of emergency; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: with the approval of Parliament, declare war. 45 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The President shall ensure that the international obligations of the Republic are fulﬁlled through the actions of the relevant Cabinet Secretaries
On the petition of any person, the President may exercise a power of mercy in accordance with the advice of the Advisory Committee established under clause
, by—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: granting a free or conditional pardon to a person convicted of an offence;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: postponing the carrying out of a punishment, either for a speciﬁed or indeﬁnite period;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: substituting a less severe form of punishment; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: remitting all or part of a punishment

clauses.text: There shall be an Advisory Committee on the Power of Mercy, comprising—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Attorney-General;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Cabinet Secretary responsible for correctional services; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: at least ﬁve other members as prescribed by an Act of Parliament, none of whom may be a State ofﬁcer or in public service

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the tenure of the members of the Advisory Committee;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the procedure of the Advisory Committee; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: criteria that shall be applied by the Advisory Committee in formulating its advice

clauses.text: The Advisory Committee may take into account the views of the victims of the offence in respect of which it is considering making recommendations to the President

articles.title: Exercise of presidential powers during temporary incumbency

clauses.text: A person who holds the ofﬁce of President or who is authorised in terms of this Constitution to exercise the powers of the President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: during the period commencing on the date of the ﬁrst vote in a presidential election, and ending when the newly elected President assumes ofﬁce; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: while the President is absent or incapacitated, or at other times contemplated in Article 147

clauses.text: , may not exercise the powers of the President speciﬁed in clause
The powers referred to in clause
are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the nomination or appointment of the judges of the superior courts;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the nomination or appointment of any other public ofﬁcer whom this Constitution or legislation requires the President to appoint;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the nomination or appointment or dismissal of Cabinet Secretaries and other State or Public ofﬁcers;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the nomination or appointment or dismissal of a high commissioner, ambassador, or diplomatic or consular representative;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the power of mercy; and

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: the authority to confer honours in the name of the people and the Republic. 46 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: A decision of the President in the performance of any function of the President under this Constitution shall be in writing and shall bear the seal and signature of the President
The President shall be elected by registered voters in a national election conducted in accordance with this Constitution and any Act of Parliament regulating presidential elections
An election of the President shall be held—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: on the same day as a general election of Members of Parliament, being the second Tuesday in August, in every ﬁfth year; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in the circumstances contemplated in Article 146

articles.title: Qualiﬁcations and disqualiﬁcations for election as President

clauses.text: A person qualiﬁes for nomination as a presidential candidate if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is a citizen by birth;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: is qualiﬁed to stand for election as a member of Parliament;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: is nominated by a political party, or is an independent candidate; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: is nominated by not fewer than two thousand voters from each of a majority of the counties

clauses.text: A person is not qualiﬁed for nomination as a presidential candidate if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: owes allegiance to a foreign state; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: is a public ofﬁcer, or is acting in any State or other public ofﬁce

clauses.text: Clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall not apply to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the President;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Deputy President; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a member of Parliament

clauses.text: If only one candidate for President is nominated, that candidate shall be declared elected
If two or more candidates for President are nominated, an election shall be held in each constituency
In a presidential election—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: all persons registered as voters for the purposes of parliamentary elections are entitled to vote;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the poll shall be taken by secret ballot on the day speciﬁed in Article 101

clauses.text: at the time, in the places and in the manner prescribed under an Act of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: after counting the votes in the polling stations, the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall tally and verify the count and declare the result

clauses.text: A candidate shall be declared elected as President if the candidate receives—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: more than half of all the votes cast in the election; and 47 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: at least twenty-ﬁve per cent of the votes cast in each of more than half of the counties

clauses.text: If no candidate is elected, a fresh election shall be held within thirty days after the previous election and in that fresh election the only candidates shall be—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the candidate, or the candidates, who received the greatest number of votes; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the candidate, or the candidates, who received the second greatest number of votes

clauses.text: If more than one candidate receives the greatest number of votes, clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall not apply and the only candidates in the fresh election shall be those contemplated in clause

clauses.text: The candidate who receives the most votes in the fresh election shall be declared elected as President
A presidential election shall be cancelled and a new election held if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: no person has been nominated as a candidate before the expiry of the period set for the delivery of nominations;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a candidate for election as President or Deputy President dies on or before the scheduled election date; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a candidate who would have been entitled to be declared elected as President, dies before being declared elected as President

clauses.text: A new presidential election under clause
shall be held within sixty days after the date set for the previous presidential election
Within seven days after the presidential election, the chairperson of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: declare the result of the election; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: deliver a written notiﬁcation of the result to the Chief Justice and the incumbent President

clauses.text: If a President-elect dies after being declared elected as President, but before assuming ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Deputy President-elect shall be sworn in as acting President on the date on which the President-elect would otherwise have been sworn-in; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a fresh election to the ofﬁce of President shall be held within sixty days after the death of the President-elect

clauses.text: If the Deputy President-elect dies before assuming ofﬁce, the ofﬁce of the Deputy President shall be declared vacant on the assumption of ofﬁce by the person declared elected as the President
If both the persons declared elected as the President and the Deputy President die before assuming ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker of the National Assembly shall act as President from the date on which the President-elect would otherwise have been sworn-in; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a fresh presidential election shall be conducted within sixty days after the second death

articles.title: Questions as to validity of presidential election

clauses.text: A person may ﬁle a petition in the Supreme Court to challenge the election of the President-elect within seven days after the date of the declaration of the results of the presidential election
Within fourteen days after the ﬁling of a petition under clause
, the Supreme Court shall hear and determine the petition and its decision shall be ﬁnal. 48 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
If the Supreme Court determines the election of the President-elect to be invalid, a fresh election shall be held within sixty days after the determination
The swearing in of the President-elect shall be in public before the Chief Justice, or, in the absence of the Chief Justice, the Deputy Chief Justice
The President-elect shall be sworn in on the ﬁrst Tuesday following—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the fourteenth day after the date of the declaration of the result of the presidential election, if no petition has been ﬁled under Article 140; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the seventh day following the date on which the court renders a decision declaring the election to be valid, if any petition has been ﬁled under Article 140

clauses.text: The President-elect assumes ofﬁce by taking and subscribing to the oath or afﬁrmation of allegiance, and the oath or afﬁrmation for the execution of the functions of ofﬁce, as prescribed in the Third Schedule
Parliament shall by legislation provide for the procedure and ceremony for the swearing-in of a President-elect
The President shall hold ofﬁce for a term beginning on the date on which the President was sworn in, and ending when the person next elected President in accordance with Article 136

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is sworn in

clauses.text: A person shall not hold ofﬁce as President for more than two terms
Criminal proceedings shall not be instituted or continued in any court against the President or a person performing the functions of that ofﬁce, during their tenure of ofﬁce

Civil proceedings shall not be instituted in any court against the President or the person performing the functions of that ofﬁce during their tenure of ofﬁce in respect of anything done or not done in the exercise of their powers under this Constitution
Where provision is made in law limiting the time within which proceedings under clause
or

may be brought against a person, a period of time during which the person holds or performs the functions of the ofﬁce of the President shall not be taken into account in calculating the period of time prescribed by that law
The immunity of the President under this Article shall not extend to a crime for which the President may be prosecuted under any treaty to which Kenya is party and which prohibits such immunity

articles.title: Removal of President on grounds of incapacity

clauses.text: A member of the National Assembly, supported by at least a quarter of all the members, may move a motion for the investigation of the President’s physical or mental capacity to perform the functions of ofﬁce
If a motion under clause
is supported by a majority of all the members of the National Assembly —

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker shall inform the Chief Justice of that resolution within two days; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the President shall continue to perform the functions of the ofﬁce pending the outcome of the proceedings required by this Article. 49 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: Within seven days after receiving notice of the resolution from the Speaker, the Chief Justice shall appoint a tribunal consisting of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: three persons who are qualiﬁed to practise medicine under the laws of Kenya, nominated by the body which by law is responsible for regulating the professional practice of medicine;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: one advocate of the High Court nominated by the body which by law is responsible for regulating the professional practice of advocates; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: one person nominated by the President

clauses.text: If the Chief Justice is unable to appoint a tribunal under clause
, the Deputy Chief Justice shall appoint such a tribunal
If the President is unable to nominate the person required to be nominated under clause

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: , the person shall be nominated by—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a member of the family of the President; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: if no such member is willing or able to make the nomination, by a close relative of the President

clauses.text: The tribunal shall inquire into the matter and, within fourteen days after the appointment, report to the Chief Justice and to the Speaker of the National Assembly
The Speaker shall cause the report of the tribunal to be tabled before the National Assembly within seven days after receiving it

The report of the tribunal shall be ﬁnal and not subject to appeal and if the tribunal reports that the President is capable of performing the functions of the ofﬁce, the Speaker of the National Assembly shall so announce in the National Assembly
If the tribunal reports that the President is incapable of performing the functions of the ofﬁce, the National Assembly shall vote on whether to ratify the report
If a majority of all the members of the National Assembly vote in favour of ratifying the report, the President shall cease to hold ofﬁce
A member of the National Assembly, supported by at least a third of all the members, may move a motion for the impeachment of the President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: on the ground of a gross violation of a provision of this Constitution or of any other law;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: where there are serious reasons for believing that the President has committed a crime under national or international law; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: for gross misconduct

clauses.text: If a motion under clause
is supported by at least two-thirds of all the members of the National Assembly—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker shall inform the Speaker of the Senate of that resolution within two days; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the President shall continue to perform the functions of the ofﬁce pending the outcome of the proceedings required by this Article

clauses.text: Within seven days after receiving notice of a resolution from the Speaker of the National Assembly —

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker of the Senate shall convene a meeting of the Senate to hear charges against the President; and 50 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Senate, by resolution, may appoint a special committee comprising eleven of its members to investigate the matter

clauses.text: A special committee appointed under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: investigate the matter; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: report to the Senate within ten days whether it ﬁnds the particulars of the allegations against the President to have been substantiated

clauses.text: The President shall have the right to appear and be represented before the special committee during its investigations
If the special committee reports that the particulars of any allegation against the President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: have not been substantiated, further proceedings shall not be taken under this Article in respect of that allegation; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: have been substantiated, the Senate shall, after according the President an opportunity to be heard, vote on the impeachment charges

clauses.text: If at least two-thirds of all the members of the Senate vote to uphold any impeachment charge, the President shall cease to hold ofﬁce

articles.title: Vacancy in the ofﬁce of President

clauses.text: The ofﬁce of President shall become vacant if the holder of the ofﬁce —

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: dies;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: resigns, in writing, addressed to the Speaker of the National Assembly; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: otherwise ceases to hold ofﬁce under Article 144 or 145 or under any other provision of this Constitution

clauses.text: When a vacancy occurs in the ofﬁce of President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Deputy President shall assume ofﬁce as President for the remainder of the term of the President; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: if the ofﬁce of Deputy President is vacant, or the Deputy President is unable to assume the ofﬁce of President, the Speaker of the National Assembly shall act as President and an election to the ofﬁce of President shall be held within sixty days after the vacancy arose in the ofﬁce of President

clauses.text: A person who assumes the ofﬁce of President under clause

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: , or following an election required by clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , shall, unless otherwise removed from ofﬁce under this Constitution, hold ofﬁce until a newly elected President is sworn in following the next regularly scheduled election under Article 136

clauses.text: If the Deputy President assumes ofﬁce as President under clause

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: , or a person is elected to the ofﬁce of President under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , the Deputy President, or the person elected, shall be deemed for the purposes of Article 142

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to have served a full term as President if, at the date on which the person assumed ofﬁce, more than two and a half years remain before the date of the next regularly scheduled election under Article 136

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: ; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: not to have served a term of ofﬁce as President, in any other case. 51 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The Deputy President shall be the principal assistant of the President and shall deputise for the President in the execution of the President’s functions
The Deputy President shall perform the functions conferred by this Constitution and any other functions of the President as the President may assign
Subject to Article 134, when the President is absent or is temporarily incapacitated, and during any other period that the President decides, the Deputy President shall act as the President
The Deputy President shall not hold any other State or public ofﬁce

articles.title: Election and swearing-in of Deputy President

clauses.text: Each candidate in a presidential election shall nominate a person who is qualiﬁed for nomination for election as President, as a candidate for Deputy President
For the purposes of clause
, there shall be no separate nomination process for the Deputy President and Article 137

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: shall not apply to a candidate for Deputy President

clauses.text: The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall declare the candidate nominated by the person who is elected as the President to be elected as the Deputy President
The swearing in of the Deputy President-elect shall be before the Chief Justice or, in the absence of the Chief Justice, the Deputy Chief Justice and in public
The Deputy President-elect assumes ofﬁce by taking and subscribing to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the oath or afﬁrmation of allegiance; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the oath or afﬁrmation for the execution of the functions of ofﬁce, as prescribed in the Third Schedule

clauses.text: The term of ofﬁce of the Deputy President shall run from the date of the swearing in of the Deputy President, and shall end—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: when the person next elected President at an election under Article 136

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is sworn in;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: on the Deputy President assuming the ofﬁce of President; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: on resignation, death or removal from ofﬁce of the Deputy President

clauses.text: The Deputy President may resign from ofﬁce at any time by notice, in writing, addressed to the President and the resignation shall take effect on the date and at the time speciﬁed in the notice, if any, or if a date is not speciﬁed, at noon on the day after the notice is delivered
A person shall not hold ofﬁce as Deputy President for more than two terms

articles.title: Vacancy in the ofﬁce of Deputy President

clauses.text: Within fourteen days after a vacancy in the ofﬁce of Deputy President arises, the President shall nominate a person to ﬁll the vacancy, and the National Assembly shall vote on the nomination within sixty days after receiving it
If a person assumes ofﬁce as Deputy President under clause
, then, for the purposes of Article 148
, the person shall be deemed—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to have served a full term as Deputy President if, at the date on which the person assumed ofﬁce, more than two and a half years remain before the date of the next regularly scheduled election under Article 136

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: ; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: not to have served a term of ofﬁce as Deputy President, in any other case. 52 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The Deputy President may be removed from ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: on the ground of physical or mental incapacity to perform the functions of the ofﬁce; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: on impeachment—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: on the ground of a gross violation of a provision of this Constitution or any other law; (ii) where there are serious reasons to believe that the Deputy President has committed a crime under national or international law; or (iii) for gross misconduct

clauses.text: The provisions of Articles 144 and 145 relating to the removal of the President shall apply, with the necessary modiﬁcations, to the removal of the Deputy President

articles.title: Remuneration and beneﬁts of President and Deputy President

clauses.text: The remuneration and beneﬁts payable to the President and the Deputy President shall be a charge on the Consolidated Fund
The remuneration, beneﬁts and privileges of the President and Deputy President shall not be varied to their disadvantage while in ofﬁce

The retirement beneﬁts payable to a former President and a former Deputy President, the facilities available to and the privileges enjoyed by them, shall not be varied to their disadvantage during their lifetime. Part 3 – The Cabinet
The Cabinet consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the President;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Deputy President;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the Attorney-General; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: not fewer than fourteen and not more than twenty-two Cabinet Secretaries

clauses.text: The President shall nominate and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appoint Cabinet Secretaries
A Cabinet Secretary shall not be a Member of Parliament
Each person appointed as a Cabinet Secretary—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: assumes ofﬁce by swearing or afﬁrming faithfulness to the people and the Republic of Kenya and obedience to this Constitution, before the President and in accordance with the Third Schedule; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may resign by delivering a written statement of resignation to the President

clauses.text: The President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: may re-assign a Cabinet Secretary;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may dismiss a Cabinet Secretary; and 53 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: shall dismiss a Cabinet Secretary if required to do so by a resolution adopted under clauses

clauses.text: to
A member of the National Assembly, supported by at least one-quarter of all the members of the Assembly, may propose a motion requiring the President to dismiss a Cabinet Secretary—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: on the ground of a gross violation of a provision of this Constitution or of any other law;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: where there are serious reasons for believing that the Cabinet Secretary has committed a crime under national or international law; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: for gross misconduct

clauses.text: If a motion under clause
is supported by at least one-third of the members of the National Assembly—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Assembly shall appoint a select committee comprising eleven of its members to investigate the matter; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the select committee shall, within ten days, report to the Assembly whether it ﬁnds the allegations against the Cabinet Secretary to be substantiated

clauses.text: The Cabinet Secretary has the right to appear and be represented before the select committee during its investigations
If the select committee reports that it ﬁnds the allegations—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: unsubstantiated, no further proceedings shall be taken; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: substantiated, the National Assembly shall—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: afford the Cabinet Secretary an opportunity to be heard; and (ii) vote whether to approve the resolution requiring the Cabinet Secretary to be dismissed

clauses.text: If a resolution under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: (ii) requiring the President to dismiss a Cabinet Secretary is supported by a majority of the members of the National Assembly—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Speaker shall promptly deliver the resolution to the President; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the President shall dismiss the Cabinet Secretary

articles.title: Decisions, responsibility and accountability of the Cabinet

clauses.text: A decision by the Cabinet shall be in writing
Cabinet Secretaries are accountable individually, and collectively, to the President for the exercise of their powers and the performance of their functions

A Cabinet Secretary shall attend before a committee of the National Assembly, or the Senate, when required by the committee, and answer any question concerning a matter for which the Cabinet Secretary is responsible
Cabinet Secretaries shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: act in accordance with this Constitution; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: provide Parliament with full and regular reports concerning matters under their control

clauses.text: There is established the ofﬁce of Secretary to the Cabinet, which is an ofﬁce in the public service. 54 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
The Secretary to the Cabinet shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: be nominated and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appointed by the President; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may be dismissed by the President

clauses.text: The Secretary to the Cabinet shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: have charge of the Cabinet ofﬁce;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: be responsible, subject to the directions of the Cabinet, for arranging the business, and keeping the minutes, of the Cabinet;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: convey the decisions of the Cabinet to the appropriate persons or authorities; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: have other functions as directed by the Cabinet

clauses.text: The Secretary to the Cabinet may resign from ofﬁce by giving notice, in writing, to the President
There is established the ofﬁce of Principal Secretary, which is an ofﬁce in the public service
Each State department shall be under the administration of a Principal Secretary
The President shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: nominate a person for appointment as Principal Secretary from among persons recommended by the Public Service Commission; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: with the approval of the National Assembly, appoint Principal Secretaries

clauses.text: The President may reassign a Principal Secretary
A Principal Secretary may resign from ofﬁce by giving notice, in writing, to the President. Part 4 – Other ofﬁces
There is established the ofﬁce of Attorney-General
The Attorney-General shall be nominated by the President and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appointed by the President
The qualiﬁcations for appointment as Attorney-General are the same as for appointment to the ofﬁce of Chief Justice
The Attorney-General—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is the principal legal adviser to the Government;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall represent the national government in court or in any other legal proceedings to which the national government is a party, other than criminal proceedings; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: shall perform any other functions conferred on the ofﬁce by an Act of Parliament or by the President. 55 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The Attorney-General shall have authority, with the leave of the court, to appear as a friend of the court in any civil proceedings to which the Government is not a party
The Attorney-General shall promote, protect and uphold the rule of law and defend the public interest
The powers of the Attorney-General may be exercised in person or by subordinate ofﬁcers acting in accordance with general or special instructions
There is established the ofﬁce of Director of Public Prosecutions
The Director of Public Prosecutions shall be nominated and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appointed by the President
The qualiﬁcations for appointment as Director of Public Prosecutions are the same as for the appointment as a judge of the High Court

The Director of Public Prosecutions shall have power to direct the Inspector-General of the National Police Service to investigate any information or allegation of criminal conduct and the Inspector-General shall comply with any such direction
The Director of Public Prosecutions shall hold ofﬁce for a term of eight years and shall not be eligible for reappointment
The Director of Public Prosecutions shall exercise State powers of prosecution and may—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: institute and undertake criminal proceedings against any person before any court (other than a court martial) in respect of any offence alleged to have been committed;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: take over and continue any criminal proceedings commenced in any court (other than a court martial) that have been instituted or undertaken by another person or authority, with the permission of the person or authority; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: subject to clause

clauses.text: and
, discontinue at any stage before judgment is delivered any criminal proceedings instituted by the Director of Public Prosecutions or taken over by the Director of Public Prosecutions under paragraph
If the discontinuance of any proceedings under clause

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: takes place after the close of the prosecution’s case, the defendant shall be acquitted

clauses.text: The Director of Public Prosecutions may not discontinue a prosecution without the permission of the court
The powers of the Director of Public Prosecutions may be exercised in person or by subordinate ofﬁcers acting in accordance with general or special instructions

The Director of Public Prosecutions shall not require the consent of any person or authority for the commencement of criminal proceedings and in the exercise of his or her powers or functions, shall not be under the direction or control of any person or authority

In exercising the powers conferred by this Article, the Director of Public Prosecutions shall have regard to the public interest, the interests of the administration of justice and the need to prevent and avoid abuse of the legal process
Parliament may enact legislation conferring powers of prosecution on authorities other than the Director of Public Prosecutions. 56 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

articles.title: Removal and resignation of Director of Public Prosecutions

clauses.text: The Director of Public Prosecutions may be removed from ofﬁce only on the grounds of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: inability to perform the functions of ofﬁce arising from mental or physical incapacity;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: non-compliance with Chapter Six;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: bankruptcy;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: incompetence; or

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: gross misconduct or misbehaviour

clauses.text: A person desiring the removal of the Director of Public Prosecutions may present a petition to the Public Service Commission which, shall be in writing, setting out the alleged facts constituting the grounds for the removal of the Director
The Public Service Commission shall consider the petition and, if it is satisﬁed that it discloses the existence of a ground under clause
, it shall send the petition to the President
On receipt and examination of the petition, the President shall, within fourteen days, suspend the Director of Public Prosecutions from ofﬁce pending action by the President in accordance with clause
and shall, acting in accordance with the advice of the Public Service Commission, appoint a tribunal consisting of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: four members from among persons who hold or have held ofﬁce as a judge of a superior court, or who are qualiﬁed to be appointed as such;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: one advocate of at least ﬁfteen years’ standing nominated by the statutory body responsible for the professional regulation of advocates; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: two other persons with experience in public affairs

clauses.text: The tribunal shall inquire into the matter expeditiously and report on the facts and make recommendations to the President, who shall act in accordance with the recommendations of the tribunal
A Director of Public Prosecutions who is suspended from ofﬁce under clause
shall be entitled to half of his or her remuneration until removed from, or reinstated in, ofﬁce
A tribunal appointed under clause
shall elect a chairperson from among its members
A tribunal appointed under clause
shall be responsible for the regulation of its proceedings
The Director of Public Prosecutions may resign from ofﬁce by giving notice, in writing, to the President
Judicial authority is derived from the people and vests in, and shall be exercised by, the courts and tribunals established by or under this Constitution. 57 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
In exercising judicial authority, the courts and tribunals shall be guided by the following principles —

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: justice shall be done to all, irrespective of status;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: justice shall not be delayed;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: alternative forms of dispute resolution including reconciliation, mediation, arbitration and traditional dispute resolution mechanisms shall be promoted, subject to clause

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: justice shall be administered without undue regard to procedural technicalities; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the purpose and principles of this Constitution shall be protected and promoted

clauses.text: Traditional dispute resolution mechanisms shall not be used in a way that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: contravenes the Bill of Rights;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: is repugnant to justice and morality or results in outcomes that are repugnant to justice or morality; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: is inconsistent with this Constitution or any written law

clauses.text: In the exercise of judicial authority, the Judiciary, as constituted by Article 161, shall be subject only to this Constitution and the law and shall not be subject to the control or direction of any person or authority
The ofﬁce of a judge of a superior court shall not be abolished while there is a substantive holder of the ofﬁce
The remuneration and beneﬁts payable to or in respect of judges shall be a charge on the Consolidated Fund
Subject to Article 168

, the remuneration and beneﬁts payable to, or in respect of, a judge shall not be varied to the disadvantage of that judge, and the retirement beneﬁts of a retired judge shall not be varied to the disadvantage of the retired judge during the lifetime of that retired judge
A member of the Judiciary is not liable in an action or suit in respect of anything done or omitted to be done in good faith in the lawful performance of a judicial function
The Judiciary consists of the judges of the superior courts, magistrates, other judicial ofﬁcers and staff
There is established the ofﬁce of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: Chief Justice, who shall be the Head of the Judiciary;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: Deputy Chief Justice, who shall be the Deputy Head of the Judiciary; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: Chief Registrar of the Judiciary, who shall be the chief administrator and accounting ofﬁcer of the Judiciary

clauses.text: The Judicial Service Commission may establish other ofﬁces of registrar as may be necessary
The superior courts are the Supreme Court, the Court of Appeal, the High Court and the courts referred to in clause
. 58 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Parliament shall establish courts with the status of the High Court to hear and determine disputes relating to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: employment and labour relations; and

subClauses.label: b
