subClauses.text: the environment and the use and occupation of, and title to, land

clauses.text: Parliament shall determine the jurisdiction and functions of the courts contemplated in clause
The subordinate courts are the courts established under Article 169, or by Parliament in accordance with that Article. Part 2 – Superior Courts
There is established the Supreme Court, which shall consist of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Chief Justice, who shall be the president of the court;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Deputy Chief Justice, who shall—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: deputise for the Chief Justice; and (ii) be the vice-president of the court; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: ﬁve other judges

clauses.text: The Supreme Court shall be properly constituted for the purposes of its proceedings if it is composed of ﬁve judges
The Supreme Court shall have—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: exclusive original jurisdiction to hear and determine disputes relating to the elections to the ofﬁce of President arising under Article 140; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: subject to clause

clauses.text: and
, appellate jurisdiction to hear and determine appeals from—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the Court of Appeal; and (ii) any other court or tribunal as prescribed by national legislation

clauses.text: Appeals shall lie from the Court of Appeal to the Supreme Court—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: as of right in any case involving the interpretation or application of this Constitution; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in any other case in which the Supreme Court, or the Court of Appeal, certiﬁes that a matter of general public importance is involved, subject to clause

clauses.text: A certiﬁcation by the Court of Appeal under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may be reviewed by the Supreme Court, and either afﬁrmed, varied or overturned

clauses.text: The Supreme Court may give an advisory opinion at the request of the national government, any State organ, or any county government with respect to any matter concerning county government
All courts, other than the Supreme Court, are bound by the decisions of the Supreme Court
The Supreme Court shall make rules for the exercise of its jurisdiction
An Act of Parliament may make further provision for the operation of the Supreme Court. 59 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
There is established the Court of Appeal, which—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: shall consist of the number of judges, being not fewer than twelve, as may be prescribed by an Act of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall be organised and administered in the manner prescribed by an Act of Parliament

clauses.text: There shall be a president of the Court of Appeal who shall be elected by the judges of the Court of Appeal from among themselves
The Court of Appeal has jurisdiction to hear appeals from—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the High Court; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any other court or tribunal as prescribed by an Act of Parliament

clauses.text: There is established the High Court, which—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: shall consist of the number of judges prescribed by an Act of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall be organised and administered in the manner prescribed by an Act of Parliament

clauses.text: There shall be a Principal Judge of the High Court, who shall be elected by the judges of the High Court from among themselves
Subject to clause
, the High Court shall have—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: unlimited original jurisdiction in criminal and civil matters;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: jurisdiction to determine the question whether a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights has been denied, violated, infringed or threatened;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: jurisdiction to hear an appeal from a decision of a tribunal appointed under this Constitution to consider the removal of a person from ofﬁce, other than a tribunal appointed under Article 144;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: jurisdiction to hear any question respecting the interpretation of this Constitution including the determination of—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the question whether any law is inconsistent with or in contravention of this Constitution; (ii) the question whether anything said to be done under the authority of this Constitution or of any law is inconsistent with, or in contravention of, this Constitution; (iii) any matter relating to constitutional powers of State organs in respect of county governments and any matter relating to the constitutional relationship between the levels of government; and (iv) a question relating to conﬂict of laws under Article 191; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: any other jurisdiction, original or appellate, conferred on it by legislation

clauses.text: Any matter certiﬁed by the court as raising a substantial question of law under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: shall be heard by an uneven number of judges, being not less than three, assigned by the Chief Justice. 60 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The High Court shall not have jurisdiction in respect of matters—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: reserved for the exclusive jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under this Constitution; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: falling within the jurisdiction of the courts contemplated in Article 162

clauses.text: The High Court has supervisory jurisdiction over the subordinate courts and over any person, body or authority exercising a judicial or quasi-judicial function, but not over a superior court
For the purposes of clause
, the High Court may call for the record of any proceedings before any subordinate court or person, body or authority referred to in clause
, and may make any order or give any direction it considers appropriate to ensure the fair administration of justice

articles.title: Appointment of Chief Justice, Deputy Chief Justice and other judges

clauses.text: The President shall appoint—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Chief Justice and the Deputy Chief Justice, in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Service Commission, and subject to the approval of the National Assembly; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: all other judges, in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Service Commission

clauses.text: Each judge of a superior court shall be appointed from among persons who—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: hold a law degree from a recognised university, or are advocates of the High Court of Kenya, or possess an equivalent qualiﬁcation in a common-law jurisdiction;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: possess the experience required under clause

clauses.text: to
as applicable, irrespective of whether that experience was gained in Kenya or in another Commonwealth common-law jurisdiction; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: have a high moral character, integrity and impartiality

clauses.text: The Chief Justice and other judges of the Supreme Court shall be appointed from among persons who have—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: at least ﬁfteen years’ experience as a superior court judge; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: at least ﬁfteen years’ experience as a distinguished academic, judicial ofﬁcer, legal practitioner or such experience in other relevant legal ﬁeld; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: held the qualiﬁcations speciﬁed in paragraphs

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: for a period amounting, in the aggregate, to ﬁfteen years

clauses.text: Each judge of the Court of Appeal shall be appointed from among persons who have—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: at least ten years’ experience as a superior court judge; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: at least ten years’ experience as a distinguished academic or legal practitioner or such experience in other relevant legal ﬁeld; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: held the qualiﬁcations mentioned in paragraphs

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: for a period amounting, in the aggregate, to ten years

clauses.text: Each judge of the High Court shall be appointed from among persons who have—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: at least ten years’ experience as a superior court judge or professionally qualiﬁed magistrate; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: at least ten years’ experience as a distinguished academic or legal practitioner or such experience in other relevant legal ﬁeld; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: held the qualiﬁcations speciﬁed in paragraphs

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: for a period amounting, in the aggregate, to ten years. 61 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

articles.title: Tenure of ofﬁce of the Chief Justice and other judges

clauses.text: A judge shall retire from ofﬁce on attaining the age of seventy years, but may elect to retire at any time after attaining the age of sixty-ﬁve years
The Chief Justice shall hold ofﬁce for a maximum of ten years or until retiring under clause
, whichever is the earlier
If the Chief Justice’s term of ofﬁce expires before the Chief Justice retires under clause
, the Chief Justice may continue in ofﬁce as a judge of the Supreme Court
If, on the expiry of the term of ofﬁce of a Chief Justice, the Chief Justice opts to remain on the Supreme Court under clause
, the next person appointed as Chief Justice may be selected in accordance with Article 166
, even though that appointment may result in there being more than the maximum permitted number of Supreme Court judges holding ofﬁce
The Chief Justice and any other judge may resign from ofﬁce by giving notice, in writing, to the President
A judge of a superior court may be removed from ofﬁce only on the grounds of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: inability to perform the functions of ofﬁce arising from mental or physical incapacity;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a breach of a code of conduct prescribed for judges of the superior courts by an Act of Parliament;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: bankruptcy;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: incompetence; or

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: gross misconduct or misbehaviour

clauses.text: The removal of a judge may be initiated only by the Judicial Service Commission acting on its own motion, or on the petition of any person to the Judicial Service Commission
A petition by a person to the Judicial Service Commission under clause
shall be in writing, setting out the alleged facts constituting the grounds for the judge's removal
The Judicial Service Commission shall consider the petition and, if it is satisﬁed that the petition discloses a ground for removal under clause
, send the petition to the President
The President shall, within fourteen days after receiving the petition, suspend the judge from ofﬁce and, acting in accordance with the recommendation of the Judicial Service Commission—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: in the case of the Chief Justice, appoint a tribunal consisting of—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the Speaker of the National Assembly, as chairperson; (ii) three superior court judges from common-law jurisdictions; (iii) one advocate of ﬁfteen years standing; and (iv) two other persons with experience in public affairs; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in the case of a judge other than the Chief Justice, appoint a tribunal consisting of—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: a chairperson and three other members from among persons who hold or have held ofﬁce as a judge of a superior court, or who are qualiﬁed to be appointed as such but who, in either case, have not been members of the Judicial Service Commission at any time within the immediately preceding three years; (ii) one advocate of ﬁfteen years standing; and 62 Constitution of Kenya Kenya (iii) two other persons with experience in public affairs

clauses.text: Despite Article 160
, the remuneration and beneﬁts payable to a judge who is suspended from ofﬁce under clause
shall be adjusted to one half until such time as the judge is removed from, or reinstated in, ofﬁce
A tribunal appointed under clause
shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: be responsible for the regulation of its proceedings, subject to any legislation contemplated in clause

clauses.text: ; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: inquire into the matter expeditiously and report on the facts and make binding recommendations to the President

clauses.text: A judge who is aggrieved by a decision of the tribunal under this Article may appeal against the decision to the Supreme Court, within ten days after the tribunal makes its recommendations
The President shall act in accordance with the recommendations made by the tribunal on the later of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the expiry of the time allowed for an appeal under clause

clauses.text: , if no such appeal is taken; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the completion of all rights of appeal in any proceedings allowed for under clause

clauses.text: , if such an appeal is taken and the ﬁnal order in the matter afﬁrms the tribunal’s recommendations
Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the procedure of a tribunal appointed under this Article. Part 3 – Subordinate Courts
The subordinate courts are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Magistrates' courts;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Kadhis’ courts;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the Courts Martial; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: any other court or local tribunal as may be established by an Act of Parliament, other than the courts established as required by Article 162

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation conferring jurisdiction, functions and powers on the courts established under clause
There shall be a Chief Kadhi and such number, being not fewer than three, of other Kadhis as may be prescribed under an Act of Parliament
A person shall not be qualiﬁed to be appointed to hold or act in the ofﬁce of Kadhi unless the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: professes the Muslim religion; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: possesses such knowledge of the Muslim law applicable to any sects of Muslims as qualiﬁes the person, in the opinion of the Judicial Service Commission, to hold a Kadhi’s court

clauses.text: Parliament shall establish Kadhis’ courts, each of which shall have the jurisdiction and powers conferred on it by legislation, subject to clause
. 63 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

The Chief Kadhi and the other Kadhis, or the Chief Kadhi and such of the other Kadhis (not being fewer than three in number) as may be prescribed under an Act of Parliament, shall each be empowered to hold a Kadhi’s court having jurisdiction within Kenya

The jurisdiction of a Kadhi's court shall be limited to the determination of questions of Muslim law relating to personal status, marriage, divorce or inheritance in proceedings in which all the parties profess the Muslim religion and submit to the jurisdiction of the Kadhis' courts. Part 4 – Judicial Service Commission

articles.title: Establishment of the Judicial Service Commission

clauses.text: There is established the Judicial Service Commission
The Commission shall consist of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Chief Justice, who shall be the chairperson of the Commission;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: one Supreme Court judge elected by the judges of the Supreme Court;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: one Court of Appeal judge elected by the judges of the Court of Appeal;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: one High Court judge and one magistrate, one a woman and one a man, elected by the members of the association of judges and magistrates;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the Attorney-General;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: two advocates, one a woman and one a man, each of whom has at least ﬁfteen years’ experience, elected by the members of the statutory body responsible for the professional regulation of advocates;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: one person nominated by the Public Service Commission; and

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: one woman and one man to represent the public, not being lawyers, appointed by the President with the approval of the National Assembly

clauses.text: The Chief Registrar of the Judiciary shall be the Secretary to the Commission

Members of the Commission, apart from the Chief Justice and the Attorney-General, shall hold ofﬁce, provided that they remain qualiﬁed, for a term of ﬁve years and shall be eligible to be nominated for one further term of ﬁve years

articles.title: Functions of the Judicial Service Commission

clauses.text: The Judicial Service Commission shall promote and facilitate the independence and accountability of the judiciary and the efﬁcient, effective and transparent administration of justice and shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: recommend to the President persons for appointment as judges;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: review and make recommendations on the conditions of service of—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: judges and judicial ofﬁcers, other than their remuneration; and (ii) the staff of the Judiciary;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: appoint, receive complaints against, investigate and remove from ofﬁce or otherwise discipline registrars, magistrates, other judicial ofﬁcers and other staff of the Judiciary, in the manner prescribed by an Act of Parliament;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: prepare and implement programmes for the continuing education and training of judges and judicial ofﬁcers; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: advise the national government on improving the efﬁciency of the administration of justice. 64 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: In the performance of its functions, the Commission shall be guided by the following—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: competitiveness and transparent processes of appointment of judicial ofﬁcers and other staff of the judiciary; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the promotion of gender equality

clauses.text: There is established a fund to be known as the Judiciary Fund which shall be administered by the Chief Registrar of the Judiciary
The Fund shall be used for administrative expenses of the Judiciary and such other purposes as may be necessary for the discharge of the functions of the Judiciary
Each ﬁnancial year, the Chief Registrar shall prepare estimates of expenditure for the following year, and submit them to the National Assembly for approval
Upon approval by the National Assembly, the expenditure of the Judiciary shall be a charge on the Consolidated Fund and the funds shall be paid directly into the Judiciary Fund
Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for the regulation of the Fund

The objects of the devolution of government are— (a) to promote democratic and accountable exercise of power; (b) to foster national unity by recognising diversity; (c) to give powers of self-governance to the people and enhance the participation of the people in the exercise of the powers of the State and in making decisions affecting them; (d) to recognise the right of communities to manage their own affairs and to further their development; (e) to protect and promote the interests and rights of minorities and marginalised communities; (f) to promote social and economic development and the provision of proximate, easily accessible services throughout Kenya; (g) to ensure equitable sharing of national and local resources throughout Kenya; (h) to facilitate the decentralisation of State organs, their functions and services, from the capital of Kenya; and (i) to enhance checks and balances and the separation of powers

County governments established under this Constitution shall reﬂect the following principles— (a) county governments shall be based on democratic principles and the separation of powers; (b) county governments shall have reliable sources of revenue to enable them to govern and deliver services effectively; and 65 Constitution of Kenya Kenya (c) no more than two-thirds of the members of representative bodies in each county government shall be of the same gender. Part 2 – County governments
There shall be a county government for each county, consisting of a county assembly and a county executive
Every county government shall decentralise its functions and the provision of its services to the extent that it is efﬁcient and practicable to do so
A county assembly consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: members elected by the registered voters of the wards, each ward constituting a single member constituency, on the same day as a general election of Members of Parliament, being the second Tuesday in August, in every ﬁfth year;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the number of special seat members necessary to ensure that no more than two-thirds of the membership of the assembly are of the same gender;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the number of members of marginalised groups, including persons with disabilities and the youth, prescribed by an Act of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the Speaker, who is an ex ofﬁcio member

clauses.text: The members contemplated in clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: shall, in each case, be nominated by political parties in proportion to the seats received in that election in that county by each political party under paragraph

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: in accordance with Article 90

clauses.text: The ﬁlling of special seats under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall be determined after declaration of elected members from each ward

clauses.text: A county assembly is elected for a term of ﬁve years
Each county assembly shall have a speaker elected by the county assembly from among persons who are not members of the assembly
A sitting of the county assembly shall be presided over by—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the speaker of the assembly; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in the absence of the speaker, another member of the assembly elected by the assembly

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the election and removal from ofﬁce of speakers of the county assemblies
The executive authority of the county is vested in, and exercised by, a county executive committee
The county executive committee consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the county governor and the deputy county governor; and 66 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: members appointed by the county governor, with the approval of the assembly, from among persons who are not members of the assembly

clauses.text: The number of members appointed under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall not exceed—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: one-third of the number of members of the county assembly, if the assembly has less than thirty members; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: ten, if the assembly has thirty or more members

clauses.text: The county governor and the deputy county governor are the chief executive and deputy chief executive of the county, respectively
When the county governor is absent, the deputy county governor shall act as the county governor
Members of a county executive committee are accountable to the county governor for the performance of their functions and exercise of their powers
If a vacancy arises in the ofﬁce of the county governor, the members of the county executive committee appointed under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: cease to hold ofﬁce

articles.title: Election of county governor and deputy county governor

clauses.text: The county governor shall be directly elected by the voters registered in the county, on the same day as a general election of Members of Parliament, being the second Tuesday in August, in every ﬁfth year
To be eligible for election as county governor, a person must be eligible for election as a member of the county assembly
If only one candidate for county governor is nominated, that candidate shall be declared elected
If two or more candidates are nominated, an election shall be held in the county and the candidate who receives the greatest number of votes shall be declared elected
Each candidate for election as county governor shall nominate a person who is qualiﬁed for nomination for election as county governor as a candidate for deputy governor

The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall not conduct a separate election for the deputy governor but shall declare the candidate nominated by the person who is elected county governor to have been elected as the deputy governor
A person shall not hold ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: as a county governor for more than two terms; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: as a deputy county governor for more than two terms

clauses.text: For the purposes of clause
, a person who has assumed the ofﬁce of county governor shall be deemed to have served a full term, subject only to Article 182
A county governor may be removed from ofﬁce on any of the following grounds—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: gross violation of this Constitution or any other law;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: where there are serious reasons for believing that the county governor has committed a crime under national or international law;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: abuse of ofﬁce or gross misconduct; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: physical or mental incapacity to perform the functions of ofﬁce of county governor. 67 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the procedure of removal of a county governor on any of the grounds speciﬁed in clause

articles.title: Vacancy in the ofﬁce of county governor

clauses.text: The ofﬁce of the county governor shall become vacant if the holder of the ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: dies;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: resigns, in writing, addressed to the speaker of the county assembly;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: ceases to be eligible to be elected county governor under Article 180

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: is convicted of an offence punishable by imprisonment for at least twelve months; or

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: is removed from ofﬁce under this Constitution

clauses.text: If a vacancy occurs in the ofﬁce of county governor, the deputy county governor shall assume ofﬁce as county governor for the remainder of the term of the county governor
If a person assumes ofﬁce as county governor under clause
, the person shall be deemed for the purposes of Article 180

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to have served a full term as county governor if, at the date on which the person assumed ofﬁce, more than two and a half years remain before the date of the next regularly scheduled election under Article 180

clauses.text: ; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: not to have served a term of ofﬁce as county governor, in any other case

clauses.text: If a vacancy occurs in the ofﬁce of county governor and that of deputy county governor, or if the deputy county governor is unable to act, the speaker of the county assembly shall act as county governor
If a vacancy occurs in the circumstances contemplated by clause
, an election to the ofﬁce of county governor shall be held within sixty days after the speaker assumes the ofﬁce of county governor

A person who assumes the ofﬁce of county governor under this Article shall, unless otherwise removed from ofﬁce under this Constitution, hold ofﬁce until the newly elected county governor assumes ofﬁce following the next election held under Article 180
A county executive committee shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: implement county legislation;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: implement, within the county, national legislation to the extent that the legislation so requires;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: manage and coordinate the functions of the county administration and its departments; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: perform any other functions conferred on it by this Constitution or national legislation

clauses.text: A county executive committee may prepare proposed legislation for consideration by the county assembly
The county executive committee shall provide the county assembly with full and regular reports on matters relating to the county. 68 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
National legislation shall provide for the governance and management of urban areas and cities and shall, in particular—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: establish criteria for classifying areas as urban areas and cities;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: establish the principles of governance and management of urban areas and cities; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: provide for participation by residents in the governance of urban areas and cities

clauses.text: National legislation contemplated in clause
may include mechanisms for identifying different categories of urban areas and cities, and for their governance
The legislative authority of a county is vested in, and exercised by, its county assembly
A county assembly may make any laws that are necessary for, or incidental to, the effective performance of the functions and exercise of the powers of the county government under the Fourth Schedule
A county assembly, while respecting the principle of the separation of powers, may exercise oversight over the county executive committee and any other county executive organs
A county assembly may receive and approve plans and policies for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the management and exploitation of the county’s resources; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the development and management of its infrastructure and institutions. Part 3 – Functions and powers of County governments

articles.title: Respective functions and powers of national and county governments

clauses.text: Except as otherwise provided by this Constitution, the functions and powers of the national government and the county governments, respectively, are as set out in the Fourth Schedule
A function or power that is conferred on more than one level of government is a function or power within the concurrent jurisdiction of each of those levels of government
A function or power not assigned by this Constitution or national legislation to a county is a function or power of the national government
For greater certainty, Parliament may legislate for the Republic on any matter

articles.title: Transfer of functions and powers between levels of government

clauses.text: A function or power of government at one level may be transferred to a government at the other level by agreement between the governments if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the function or power would be more effectively performed or exercised by the receiving government; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the transfer of the function or power is not prohibited by the legislation under which it is to be performed or exercised. 69 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: If a function or power is transferred from a government at one level to a government at the other level—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: arrangements shall be put in place to ensure that the resources necessary for the performance of the function or exercise of the power are transferred; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: constitutional responsibility for the performance of the function or exercise of the power shall remain with the government to which it is assigned by the Fourth Schedule. Part 4 – The boundaries of counties

clauses.text: The boundaries of a county may be altered only by a resolution—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: recommended by an independent commission set up for that purpose by Parliament; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: passed by—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the National Assembly, with the support of at least two-thirds of all of the members of the Assembly; and (ii) the Senate, with the support of at least two-thirds of all of the county delegations

clauses.text: The boundaries of a county may be altered to take into account—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: population density and demographic trends;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: physical and human infrastructure;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: historical and cultural ties;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the cost of administration;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the views of the communities affected;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: the objects of devolution of government; and

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: geographical features. Part 5 – Relationship between governments

articles.title: Cooperation between national and county governments

clauses.text: Government at either level shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: perform its functions, and exercise its powers, in a manner that respects the functional and institutional integrity of government at the other level, and respects the constitutional status and institutions of government at the other level and, in the case of county government, within the county level;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: assist, support and consult and, as appropriate, implement the legislation of the other level of government; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: liaise with government at the other level for the purpose of exchanging information, coordinating policies and administration and enhancing capacity

clauses.text: Government at each level, and different governments at the county level, shall co-operate in the performance of functions and exercise of powers and, for that purpose, may set up joint committees and joint authorities. 70 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
In any dispute between governments, the governments shall make every reasonable effort to settle the dispute, including by means of procedures provided under national legislation
National legislation shall provide procedures for settling inter-governmental disputes by alternative dispute resolution mechanisms, including negotiation, mediation and arbitration
Parliament shall by legislation ensure that county governments have adequate support to enable them to perform their functions
County governments shall operate ﬁnancial management systems that comply with any requirements prescribed by national legislation
Parliament shall, by legislation, provide for intervention by the national government if a county government—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is unable to perform its functions; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: does not operate a ﬁnancial management system that complies with the requirements prescribed by national legislation

clauses.text: Legislation under clause
may, in particular, authorise the national government—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to take appropriate steps to ensure that the county government’s functions are performed and that it operates a ﬁnancial management system that complies with the prescribed requirements; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: if necessary, to assume responsibility for the relevant functions

clauses.text: The legislation under clause
shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: require notice to be given to a county government of any measures that the national government intends to take;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: permit the national government to take only measures that are necessary;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: require the national government, when it intervenes, to take measures that will assist the county government to resume full responsibility for its functions; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: provide for a process by which the Senate may bring the intervention by the national government to an end

clauses.text: This Article applies to conﬂicts between national and county legislation in respect of matters falling within the concurrent jurisdiction of both levels of government
National legislation prevails over county legislation if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the national legislation applies uniformly throughout Kenya and any of the conditions speciﬁed in clause

clauses.text: is satisﬁed; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the national legislation is aimed at preventing unreasonable action by a county that—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: is prejudicial to the economic, health or security interests of Kenya or another county; or (ii) impedes the implementation of national economic policy

clauses.text: The following are the conditions referred to in clause

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the national legislation provides for a matter that cannot be regulated effectively by legislation enacted by the individual counties; 71 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the national legislation provides for a matter that, to be dealt with effectively, requires uniformity across the nation, and the national legislation provides that uniformity by establishing—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: norms and standards; or (ii) national policies; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the national legislation is necessary for—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the maintenance of national security; (ii) the maintenance of economic unity; (iii) the protection of the common market in respect of the mobility of goods, services, capital and labour; (iv) the promotion of economic activities across county boundaries;

subClauses.label: v
subClauses.text: the promotion of equal opportunity or equal access to government services; or (vi) the protection of the environment

clauses.text: County legislation prevails over national legislation if neither of the circumstances contemplated in clause
apply

In considering an apparent conﬂict between legislation of different levels of government, a court shall prefer a reasonable interpretation of the legislation that avoids a conﬂict to an alternative interpretation that results in conﬂict

A decision by a court that a provision of legislation of one level of government prevails over a provision of legislation of another level of government does not invalidate the other provision, but the other provision is inoperative to the extent of the inconsistency. Part 6 – Suspension of county governments
The President may suspend a county government—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: in an emergency arising out of internal conﬂict or war; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in any other exceptional circumstances

clauses.text: A county government shall not be suspended under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: unless an independent commission of inquiry has investigated allegations against the county government, the President is satisﬁed that the allegations are justiﬁed and the Senate has authorised the suspension

clauses.text: During a suspension under this Article, arrangements shall be made for the performance of the functions of a county government in accordance with an Act of Parliament
The Senate may at any time terminate the suspension
A suspension under this Article shall not extend beyond a period of ninety days
On the expiry of the period provided for under clause
, elections for the relevant county government shall be held. 72 Constitution of Kenya Kenya Part 7 – General

articles.title: Qualiﬁcations for election as member of county assembly

clauses.text: Unless disqualiﬁed under clause
, a person is eligible for election as a member of a county assembly if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is registered as a voter;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: satisﬁes any educational, moral and ethical requirements prescribed by this Constitution or an Act of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: is either—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: nominated by a political party; or (ii) an independent candidate supported by at least ﬁve hundred registered voters in the ward concerned

clauses.text: A person is disqualiﬁed from being elected a member of a county assembly if the person—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is a State ofﬁcer or other public ofﬁcer, other than a member of the county assembly;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: has, at any time within the ﬁve years immediately before the date of election, held ofﬁce as a member of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: has not been a citizen of Kenya for at least the ten years immediately preceding the date of election;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: is of unsound mind;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: is an undischarged bankrupt;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: is serving a sentence of imprisonment of at least six months; or

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: has been found, in accordance with any law, to have misused or abused a State ofﬁce or public ofﬁce or to have contravened Chapter Six

clauses.text: A person is not disqualiﬁed under clause
unless all possibility of appeal or review of the relevant sentence or decision has been exhausted

articles.title: Vacation of ofﬁce of member of county assembly

clauses.text: The ofﬁce of a member of a county assembly becomes vacant—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: if the member dies;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: if the member is absent from eight sittings of the assembly without permission, in writing, of the speaker of the assembly, and is unable to offer satisfactory explanation for the absence;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: if the member is removed from ofﬁce under this Constitution or legislation enacted under Article 80;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: if the member resigns in writing addressed to the speaker of the assembly;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: if, having been elected to the assembly—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: as a member of a political party, the member resigns from the party, or is deemed to have resigned from the party as determined in accordance with the legislation contemplated in clause

clauses.text: ; or (ii) as an independent candidate, the member joins a political party;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: at the end of the term of the assembly; or 73 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: if the member becomes disqualiﬁed for election on grounds speciﬁed in Article 193

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the circumstances under which a member of a political party shall be deemed, for the purposes of clause

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: , to have resigned from the party

articles.title: County assembly power to summon witnesses

clauses.text: A county assembly or any of its committees has power to summon any person to appear before it for the purpose of giving evidence or providing information
For the purposes of clause
, an assembly has the same powers as the High Court to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: enforce the attendance of witnesses and examining them on oath, afﬁrmation or otherwise;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: compel the production of documents; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: issue a commission or request to examine witnesses abroad

articles.title: Public participation and county assembly powers, privileges and immunities

clauses.text: A county assembly shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: conduct its business in an open manner, and hold its sittings and those of its committees, in public; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: facilitate public participation and involvement in the legislative and other business of the assembly and its committees

clauses.text: A county assembly may not exclude the public, or any media, from any sitting unless in exceptional circumstances the speaker has determined that there are justiﬁable reasons for doing so
Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the powers, privileges and immunities of county assemblies, their committees and members

articles.title: County assembly gender balance and diversity

clauses.text: Not more than two-thirds of the members of any county assembly or county executive committee shall be of the same gender
Parliament shall enact legislation to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: ensure that the community and cultural diversity of a county is reﬂected in its county assembly and county executive committee; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: prescribe mechanisms to protect minorities within counties

clauses.text: While an election is being held to constitute a county assembly under this Chapter, the executive committee of the county, as last constituted remains competent to perform administrative functions until a new executive committee is constituted after the election
County legislation does not take effect unless published in the Gazette
National and county legislation may prescribe additional requirements in respect of the publication of county legislation. 74 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Parliament shall enact legislation providing for all matters necessary or convenient to give effect to this Chapter
In particular, provision may be made with respect to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the governance of the capital city, other cities and urban areas;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the transfer of functions and powers by one level of government to another, including the transfer of legislative powers from the national government to county governments;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the manner of election or appointment of persons to, and their removal from, ofﬁces in county governments, including the qualiﬁcations of voters and candidates;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the procedure of assemblies and executive committees including the chairing and frequency of meetings, quorums and voting; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the suspension of assemblies and executive committees

clauses.text: The following principles shall guide all aspects of public ﬁnance in the Republic— (a) there shall be openness and accountability, including public participation in ﬁnancial matters; (b) the public ﬁnance system shall promote an equitable society, and in particular— (i) the burden of taxation shall be shared fairly; (ii) revenue raised nationally shall be shared equitably among national and county governments; and (iii) expenditure shall promote the equitable development of the country, including by making special provision for marginalised groups and areas; (c) the burden and beneﬁts of the use of resources and public borrowing shall be shared equitably between present and future generations; (d) public money shall be used in a prudent and responsible way; and (e) ﬁnancial management shall be responsible, and ﬁscal reporting shall be clear
Revenue raised nationally shall be shared equitably among the national and county governments
County governments may be given additional allocations from the national government’s share of the revenue, either conditionally or unconditionally. 75 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

articles.title: Equitable share and other ﬁnancial laws

clauses.text: The following criteria shall be taken into account in determining the equitable shares provided for under Article 202 and in all national legislation concerning county government enacted in terms of this Chapter—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the national interest;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any provision that must be made in respect of the public debt and other national obligations;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the needs of the national government, determined by objective criteria;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the need to ensure that county governments are able to perform the functions allocated to them;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the ﬁscal capacity and efﬁciency of county governments;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: developmental and other needs of counties;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: economic disparities within and among counties and the need to remedy them;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: the need for afﬁrmative action in respect of disadvantaged areas and groups;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the need for economic optimisation of each county and to provide incentives for each county to optimise its capacity to raise revenue;

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: the desirability of stable and predictable allocations of revenue; and

subClauses.label: k
subClauses.text: the need for ﬂexibility in responding to emergencies and other temporary needs, based on similar objective criteria

clauses.text: For every ﬁnancial year, the equitable share of the revenue raised nationally that is allocated to county governments shall be not less than ﬁfteen per cent of all revenue collected by the national government
The amount referred to in clause
shall be calculated on the basis of the most recent audited accounts of revenue received, as approved by the National Assembly

There is established an Equalisation Fund into which shall be paid one half per cent of all the revenue collected by the national government each year calculated on the basis of the most recent audited accounts of revenue received, as approved by the National Assembly

The national government shall use the Equalisation Fund only to provide basic services including water, roads, health facilities and electricity to marginalised areas to the extent necessary to bring the quality of those services in those areas to the level generally enjoyed by the rest of the nation, so far as possible
The national government may use the Equalisation Fund—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: only to the extent that the expenditure of those funds has been approved in an Appropriation Bill enacted by Parliament; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: either directly, or indirectly through conditional grants to counties in which marginalised communities exist

clauses.text: The Commission on Revenue Allocation shall be consulted and its recommendations considered before Parliament passes any Bill appropriating money out of the Equalisation Fund
Any unexpended money in the Equalisation Fund at the end of a particular ﬁnancial year shall remain in that Fund for use in accordance with clauses
and
during any subsequent ﬁnancial year. 76 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
This Article lapses twenty years after the effective date, subject to clause
Parliament may enact legislation suspending the effect of clause
for a further ﬁxed period of years, subject to clause
Legislation under clause
shall be supported by more than half of all the members of the National Assembly, and more than half of all the county delegations in the Senate
Money shall not be withdrawn from the Equalisation Fund unless the Controller of Budget has approved the withdrawal

articles.title: Consultation on ﬁnancial legislation affecting counties

clauses.text: When a Bill that includes provisions dealing with the sharing of revenue, or any ﬁnancial matter concerning county governments is published, the Commission on Revenue Allocation shall consider those provisions and may make recommendations to the National Assembly and the Senate
Any recommendations made by the Commission shall be tabled in Parliament, and each House shall consider the recommendations before voting on the Bill. Part 2 – Other public funds

articles.title: Consolidated Fund and other public funds

clauses.text: There is established the Consolidated Fund into which shall be paid all money raised or received by or on behalf of the national government, except money that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is reasonably excluded from the Fund by an Act of Parliament and payable into another public fund established for a speciﬁc purpose; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may, under an Act of Parliament, be retained by the State organ that received it for the purpose of defraying the expenses of the State organ

clauses.text: Money may be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund only—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: in accordance with an appropriation by an Act of Parliament;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: in accordance with Article 222 or 223; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: as a charge against the Fund as authorised by this Constitution or an Act of Parliament

clauses.text: Money shall not be withdrawn from any national public fund other than the Consolidated Fund, unless the withdrawal of the money has been authorised by an Act of Parliament
Money shall not be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund unless the Controller of Budget has approved the withdrawal

There shall be established a Revenue Fund for each county government, into which shall be paid all money raised or received by or on behalf of the county government, except money reasonably excluded by an Act of Parliament
Money may be withdrawn from the Revenue Fund of a county government only—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: as a charge against the Revenue Fund that is provided for by an Act of Parliament or by legislation of the county; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: as authorised by an appropriation by legislation of the county

clauses.text: Money shall not be withdrawn from a Revenue Fund unless the Controller of Budget has approved the withdrawal. 77 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
An Act of Parliament may—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: make further provision for the withdrawal of funds from a county Revenue Fund; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: provide for the establishment of other funds by counties and the management of those funds

clauses.text: There is established a Contingencies Fund, the operation of which shall be in accordance with an Act of Parliament

An Act of Parliament shall provide for advances from the Contingencies Fund if the Cabinet Secretary responsible for ﬁnance is satisﬁed that there is an urgent and unforeseen need for expenditure for which there is no other authority. Part 3 – Revenue-raising and the public debt

articles.title: Power to impose taxes and charges

clauses.text: Only the national government may impose—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: income tax;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: value-added tax;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: customs duties and other duties on import and export goods; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: excise tax

clauses.text: An Act of Parliament may authorise the national government to impose any other tax or duty, except a tax speciﬁed in clause

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: or

clauses.text: A county may impose—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: property rates;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: entertainment taxes; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: any other tax that it is authorised to impose by an Act of Parliament

clauses.text: The national and county governments may impose charges for services

The taxation and other revenue-raising powers of a county shall not be exercised in a way that prejudices national economic policies, economic activities across county boundaries or the national mobility of goods, services, capital or labour
No tax or licensing fee may be imposed, waived or varied except as provided by legislation
If legislation permits the waiver of any tax or licensing fee—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a public record of each waiver shall be maintained together with the reason for the waiver; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: each waiver, and the reason for it, shall be reported to the Auditor-General

clauses.text: No law may exclude or authorise the exclusion of a State ofﬁcer from payment of tax by reason of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the ofﬁce held by that State ofﬁcer; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the nature of the work of the State ofﬁcer. 78 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: Parliament may, by legislation—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: prescribe the terms on which the national government may borrow; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: impose reporting requirements

clauses.text: Within seven days after either House of Parliament so requests by resolution, the Cabinet Secretary responsible for ﬁnance shall present to the relevant committee, information concerning any particular loan or guarantee, including all information necessary to show—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the extent of the total indebtedness by way of principal and accumulated interest;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the use made or to be made of the proceeds of the loan;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the provision made for servicing or repayment of the loan; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the progress made in the repayment of the loan

clauses.text: A county government may borrow only— (a) if the national government guarantees the loan; and (b) with the approval of the county government’s assembly
An Act of Parliament shall prescribe terms and conditions under which the national government may guarantee loans
Within two months after the end of each ﬁnancial year, the national government shall publish a report on the guarantees that it gave during that year
The public debt is a charge on the Consolidated Fund, but an Act of Parliament may provide for charging all or part of the public debt to other public funds

For the purposes of this Article, "the public debt" means all ﬁnancial obligations attendant to loans raised or guaranteed and securities issued or guaranteed by the national government. Part 4 – Revenue allocation
There is established the Commission on Revenue Allocation
The Commission shall consist of the following persons appointed by the President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a chairperson, who shall be nominated by the President and approved by the National Assembly;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: two persons nominated by the political parties represented in the National Assembly according to their proportion of members in the Assembly;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: ﬁve persons nominated by the political parties represented in the Senate according to their proportion of members in the Senate; and 79 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the Principal Secretary in the Ministry responsible for ﬁnance

clauses.text: The persons nominated under clause
shall not be members of Parliament
To be qualiﬁed to be a member of the Commission under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: , a person shall have extensive professional experience in ﬁnancial and economic matters

articles.title: Functions of the Commission on Revenue Allocation

clauses.text: The principal function of the Commission on Revenue Allocation is to make recommendations concerning the basis for the equitable sharing of revenue raised by the national government—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: between the national and county governments; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: among the county governments

clauses.text: The Commission shall also make recommendations on other matters concerning the ﬁnancing of, and ﬁnancial management by, county governments, as required by this Constitution and national legislation
In formulating recommendations, the Commission shall seek—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to promote and give effect to the criteria set out in Article 203

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: when appropriate, to deﬁne and enhance the revenue sources of the national and county governments; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to encourage ﬁscal responsibility

clauses.text: The Commission shall determine, publish and regularly review a policy in which it sets out the criteria by which to identify the marginalised areas for purposes of Article 204
The Commission shall submit its recommendations to the Senate, the National Assembly, the national executive, county assemblies and county executives
Once every ﬁve years, the Senate shall, by resolution, determine the basis for allocating among the counties the share of national revenue that is annually allocated to the county level of government
In determining the basis of revenue sharing under clause
, the Senate shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: take the criteria in Article 203

clauses.text: into account;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: request and consider recommendations from the Commission on Revenue Allocation;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: consult the county governors, the Cabinet Secretary responsible for ﬁnance and any organisation of county governments; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: invite the public, including professional bodies, to make submissions to it on the matter

clauses.text: Within ten days after the Senate adopts a resolution under clause
, the Speaker of the Senate shall refer the resolution to the Speaker of the National Assembly
Within sixty days after the Senate’s resolution is referred under clause
, the National Assembly may consider the resolution, and vote to approve it, with or without amendments, or to reject it
If the National Assembly—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: does not vote on the resolution within sixty days, the resolution shall be regarded as having been approved by the National Assembly without amendment; or 80 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: votes on the resolution, the resolution shall have been—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: amended only if at least two-thirds of the members of the Assembly vote in support of an amendment; (ii) rejected only if at least two-thirds of the members of the Assembly vote against it, irrespective whether it has ﬁrst been amended by the Assembly; or (iii) approved, in any other case

clauses.text: If the National Assembly approves an amended version of the resolution, or rejects the resolution, the Senate, at its option, may either—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: adopt a new resolution under clause

clauses.text: , in which case the provisions of this clause and clauses
and
apply afresh; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: request that the matter be referred to a joint committee of the two Houses of Parliament for mediation under Article 113, applied with the necessary modiﬁcations

clauses.text: A resolution under this Article that is approved under clause
shall be binding until a subsequent resolution has been approved
Despite clause
, the Senate may, by resolution supported by at least two-thirds of its members, amend a resolution at any time after it has been approved
Clause
to
, with the necessary modiﬁcations, apply to a resolution under clause

articles.title: Annual Division and Allocation of Revenue Bills

clauses.text: At least two months before the end of each ﬁnancial year, there shall be introduced in Parliament—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a Division of Revenue Bill, which shall divide revenue raised by the national government among the national and county levels of government in accordance with this Constitution; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a County Allocation of Revenue Bill, which shall divide among the counties the revenue allocated to the county level of government on the basis determined in accordance with the resolution in force under Article 217

clauses.text: Each Bill required by clause
shall be accompanied by a memorandum setting out—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: an explanation of revenue allocation as proposed by the Bill;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: an evaluation of the Bill in relation to the criteria set out in Article 203

clauses.text: ; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a summary of any signiﬁcant deviation from the Commission on Revenue Allocation’s recommendations, with an explanation for each such deviation

clauses.text: A county’s share of revenue raised by the national government shall be transferred to the county without undue delay and without deduction, except when the transfer has been stopped under Article 225. Part 5 – Budgets and spending

articles.title: Form, content and timing of budgets

clauses.text: Budgets of the national and county governments shall contain—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: estimates of revenue and expenditure, differentiating between recurrent and development expenditure; 81 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: proposals for ﬁnancing any anticipated deﬁcit for the period to which they apply; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: proposals regarding borrowing and other forms of public liability that will increase public debt during the following year

clauses.text: National legislation shall prescribe—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the structure of the development plans and budgets of counties;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: when the plans and budgets of the counties shall be tabled in the county assemblies; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the form and manner of consultation between the national government and county governments in the process of preparing plans and budgets

articles.title: Budget estimates and annual Appropriation Bill

clauses.text: At least two months before the end of each ﬁnancial year, the Cabinet Secretary responsible for ﬁnance shall submit to the National Assembly estimates of the revenue and expenditure of the national government for the next ﬁnancial year to be tabled in the National Assembly
The estimates referred to in clause
shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: include estimates for expenditure from the Equalisation Fund; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: be in the form, and according to the procedure, prescribed by an Act of Parliament

clauses.text: The National Assembly shall consider the estimates submitted under clause
together with the estimates submitted by the Parliamentary Service Commission and the Chief Registrar of the Judiciary under Articles 127 and 173 respectively
Before the National Assembly considers the estimates of revenue and expenditure, a committee of the Assembly shall discuss and review the estimates and make recommendations to the Assembly

In discussing and reviewing the estimates, the committee shall seek representations from the public and the recommendations shall be taken into account when the committee makes its recommendations to the National Assembly

When the estimates of national government expenditure, and the estimates of expenditure for the Judiciary and Parliament have been approved by the National Assembly, they shall be included in an Appropriation Bill, which shall be introduced into the National Assembly to authorise the withdrawal from the Consolidated Fund of the money needed for the expenditure, and for the appropriation of that money for the purposes mentioned in the Bill
The Appropriation Bill mentioned in clause
shall not include expenditures that are charged on the Consolidated Fund by this Constitution or an Act of Parliament

articles.title: Expenditure before annual budget is passed

clauses.text: If the Appropriation Act for a ﬁnancial year has not been assented to, or is not likely to be assented to, by the beginning of that ﬁnancial year, the National Assembly may authorise the withdrawal of money from the Consolidated Fund
Money withdrawn under clause
shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: be for the purpose of meeting expenditure necessary to carry on the services of the national government during that year until such time as the Appropriation Act is assented to;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: not exceed in total one-half of the amount included in the estimates of expenditure for that year that have been tabled in the National Assembly; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: be included, under separate votes for the several services in respect of which they were withdrawn, in the Appropriation Act. 82 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: Subject to clauses
to
, the national government may spend money that has not been appropriated if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the amount appropriated for any purpose under the Appropriation Act is insufﬁcient or a need has arisen for expenditure for a purpose for which no amount has been appropriated by that Act; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: money has been withdrawn from the Contingencies Fund

clauses.text: The approval of Parliament for any spending under this Article shall be sought within two months after the ﬁrst withdrawal of the money, subject to clause
If Parliament is not sitting during the time contemplated in clause
, or is sitting but adjourns before the approval has been sought, the approval shall be sought within two weeks after it next sits
When the National Assembly has approved spending under clause
, an appropriation Bill shall be introduced for the appropriation of the money spent

In any particular ﬁnancial year, the national government may not spend under this Article more than ten per cent of the sum appropriated by Parliament for that ﬁnancial year unless, in special circumstances, Parliament has approved a higher percentage

On the basis of the Division of Revenue Bill passed by Parliament under Article 218, each county government shall prepare and adopt its own annual budget and appropriation Bill in the form, and according to the procedure, prescribed in an Act of Parliament. Part 6 – Control of public money
An Act of Parliament shall provide for the establishment, functions and responsibilities of the national Treasury
Parliament shall enact legislation to ensure both expenditure control and transparency in all governments and establish mechanisms to ensure their implementation
Legislation under clause
may authorise the Cabinet Secretary responsible for ﬁnance to stop the transfer of funds to a State organ or any other public entity—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: only for a serious material breach or persistent material breaches of the measures established under that legislation; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: subject to the requirements of clauses

clauses.text: to
A decision to stop the transfer of funds under clause
may not stop the transfer of more than ﬁfty per cent of funds due to a county government
A decision to stop the transfer of funds as contemplated in clause

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: shall not stop the transfer of funds for more than sixty days; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may be enforced immediately, but will lapse retrospectively unless, within thirty days after the date of the decision, Parliament approves it by resolution passed by both Houses

clauses.text: Parliament may renew a decision to stop the transfer of funds but for no more than sixty days at a time. 83 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Parliament may not approve or renew a decision to stop the transfer of funds unless—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Controller of Budget has presented a report on the matter to Parliament; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the public entity has been given an opportunity to answer the allegations against it, and to state its case, before the relevant parliamentary committee

articles.title: Accounts and audit of public entities

clauses.text: An Act of Parliament shall provide for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the keeping of ﬁnancial records and the auditing of accounts of all governments and other public entities, and prescribe other measures for securing efﬁcient and transparent ﬁscal management; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the designation of an accounting ofﬁcer in every public entity at the national and county level of government

clauses.text: The accounting ofﬁcer of a national public entity is accountable to the National Assembly for its ﬁnancial management, and the accounting ofﬁcer of a county public entity is accountable to the county assembly for its ﬁnancial management
Subject to clause
, the accounts of all governments and State organs shall be audited by the Auditor-General
The accounts of the ofﬁce of the Auditor-General shall be audited and reported on by a professionally qualiﬁed accountant appointed by the National Assembly

If the holder of a public ofﬁce, including a political ofﬁce, directs or approves the use of public funds contrary to law or instructions, the person is liable for any loss arising from that use and shall make good the loss, whether the person remains the holder of the ofﬁce or not

articles.title: Procurement of public goods and services

clauses.text: When a State organ or any other public entity contracts for goods or services, it shall do so in accordance with a system that is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost-effective
An Act of Parliament shall prescribe a framework within which policies relating to procurement and asset disposal shall be implemented and may provide for all or any of the following—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: categories of preference in the allocation of contracts;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the protection or advancement of persons, categories of persons or groups previously disadvantaged by unfair competition or discrimination;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: sanctions against contractors that have not performed according to professionally regulated procedures, contractual agreements or legislation; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: sanctions against persons who have defaulted on their tax obligations, or have been guilty of corrupt practices or serious violations of fair employment laws and practices. Part 7 – Financial ofﬁcers and institutions

clauses.text: There shall be a Controller of Budget who shall be nominated by the President and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appointed by the President
To be qualiﬁed to be the Controller, a person shall have extensive knowledge of public ﬁnance or at least ten years' experience in auditing public ﬁnance management. 84 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
The Controller shall, subject to Article 251, hold ofﬁce for a term of eight years and shall not be eligible for re-appointment
The Controller of Budget shall oversee the implementation of the budgets of the national and county governments by authorising withdrawals from public funds under Articles 204, 206 and 207
The Controller shall not approve any withdrawal from a public fund unless satisﬁed that the withdrawal is authorised by law
Every four months, the Controller shall submit to each House of Parliament a report on the implementation of the budgets of the national and county governments
There shall be an Auditor-General who shall be nominated by the President and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appointed by the President
To be qualiﬁed to be the Auditor-General, a person shall have extensive knowledge of public ﬁnance or at least ten years experience in auditing or public ﬁnance management
The Auditor-General holds ofﬁce, subject to Article 251, for a term of eight years and shall not be eligible for re-appointment
Within six months after the end of each ﬁnancial year, the Auditor-General shall audit and report, in respect of that ﬁnancial year, on—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the accounts of the national and county governments;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the accounts of all funds and authorities of the national and county governments;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the accounts of all courts;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the accounts of every commission and independent ofﬁce established by this Constitution;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the accounts of the National Assembly, the Senate and the county assemblies;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: the accounts of political parties funded from public funds;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: the public debt; and

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: the accounts of any other entity that legislation requires the Auditor-General to audit

clauses.text: The Auditor-General may audit and report on the accounts of any entity that is funded from public funds
An audit report shall conﬁrm whether or not public money has been applied lawfully and in an effective way
Audit reports shall be submitted to Parliament or the relevant county assembly
Within three months after receiving an audit report, Parliament or the county assembly shall debate and consider the report and take appropriate action
There is established the Salaries and Remuneration Commission
The Salaries and Remuneration Commission consists of the following persons appointed by the President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a chairperson; 85 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: one person each nominated by the following bodies from among persons who are not members or employees of those bodies—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the Parliamentary Service Commission; (ii) the Public Service Commission; (iii) the Judicial Service Commission; (iv) the Teachers Service Commission;

subClauses.label: v
subClauses.text: the National Police Service Commission; (vi) the Defence Council; and (vii) the Senate, on behalf of the county governments;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: one person each nominated by—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: an umbrella body representing trade unions; (ii) an umbrella body representing employers; and (iii) a joint forum of professional bodies as provided by legislation;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: one person each nominated by—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the Cabinet Secretary responsible for ﬁnance; and (ii) the Attorney-General; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: one person who has experience in the management of human resources in the public service, nominated by the Cabinet Secretary responsible for public service

clauses.text: The Commissioners under clause

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: shall have no vote

clauses.text: The powers and functions of the Salaries and Remuneration Commission shall be to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: set and regularly review the remuneration and beneﬁts of all State ofﬁcers; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: advise the national and county governments on the remuneration and beneﬁts of all other public ofﬁcers

clauses.text: In performing its functions, the Commission shall take the following principles into account—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the need to ensure that the total public compensation bill is ﬁscally sustainable;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the need to ensure that the public services are able to attract and retain the skills required to execute their functions;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the need to recognise productivity and performance; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: transparency and fairness

clauses.text: There is established the Central Bank of Kenya
