The Central Bank of Kenya shall be responsible for formulating monetary policy, promoting price stability, issuing currency and performing other functions conferred on it by an Act of Parliament
The Central Bank of Kenya shall not be under the direction or control of any person or authority in the exercise of its powers or in the performance of its functions

Notes and coins issued by the Central Bank of Kenya may bear images that depict or symbolise Kenya or an aspect of Kenya but shall not bear the portrait of any individual. 86 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
An Act of Parliament shall provide for the composition, powers, functions and operations of the Central Bank of Kenya

articles.title: Values and principles of public service

clauses.text: The values and principles of public service include—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: high standards of professional ethics;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: efﬁcient, effective and economic use of resources;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: responsive, prompt, effective, impartial and equitable provision of services;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: involvement of the people in the process of policy making;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: accountability for administrative acts;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: transparency and provision to the public of timely, accurate information;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: subject to paragraphs

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: , fair competition and merit as the basis of appointments and promotions;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: representation of Kenya’s diverse communities; and

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: affording adequate and equal opportunities for appointment, training and advancement, at all levels of the public service, of—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: men and women; (ii) the members of all ethnic groups; and (iii) persons with disabilities

clauses.text: The values and principles of public service apply to public service in—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: all State organs in both levels of government; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: all State corporations

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to this Article. Part 2 – The Public Service Commission
There is established the Public Service Commission
The Public Service Commission consists of a chairperson, a vice chairperson and seven other members appointed by the President with the approval of the National Assembly
Subject to clause
, a person is not eligible for appointment as a member of the Commission if the person–—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: has, at any time within the preceding ﬁve years, held ofﬁce, or stood for election as—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: a member of Parliament or of a county assembly; or 87 Constitution of Kenya Kenya (ii) a member of the governing body of a political party; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: holds any State ofﬁce;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: is, or has at any time been, a candidate for election as a member of Parliament or of a county assembly; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: is, or has at any time been, the holder of an ofﬁce in any political organisation that sponsors or otherwise supports, or has at any time sponsored or otherwise supported, a candidate for election as a member of Parliament or of a county assembly

clauses.text: Clause

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: cease to apply to a person after two general elections for Parliament have been held since the person ceased to be such a candidate or ofﬁce holder

clauses.text: There shall be a secretary to the Commission
The secretary–—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is the chief executive of the Commission; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall be appointed by the Commission for a term of ﬁve years, and is eligible for re- appointment once

articles.title: Functions and powers of the Public Service Commission

clauses.text: The functions and powers of the Commission are as set out in this Article
The Commission shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: subject to this Constitution and legislation—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: establish and abolish ofﬁces in the public service; and (ii) appoint persons to hold or act in those ofﬁces, and to conﬁrm appointments;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: exercise disciplinary control over and remove persons holding or acting in those ofﬁces;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: promote the values and principles referred to in Articles 10 and 232 throughout the public service;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: investigate, monitor and evaluate the organisation, administration and personnel practices of the public service;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: ensure that the public service is efﬁcient and effective;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: develop human resources in the public service;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: review and make recommendations to the national government in respect of conditions of service, code of conduct and qualiﬁcations of ofﬁcers in the public service;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: evaluate and report to the President and Parliament on the extent to which the values and principles referred to in Articles 10 and 232 are complied with in the public service;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: hear and determine appeals in respect of county governments’ public service; and

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: perform any other functions and exercise any other powers conferred by national legislation

clauses.text: Clauses
and
shall not apply to any of the following ofﬁces in the public service—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: State ofﬁces;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: an ofﬁce of high commissioner, ambassador or other diplomatic or consular representative of the Republic; 88 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: an ofﬁce or position subject to—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the Parliamentary Service Commission; (ii) the Judicial Service Commission; (iii) the Teachers Service Commission; (iv) the National Police Service Commission; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: an ofﬁce in the service of a county government, except as contemplated in clause

clauses.text: The Commission shall not appoint a person under clause
to hold or act in any ofﬁce on the personal staff of the President or a retired President, except with the consent of the President or retired President

The Commission may delegate, in writing, with or without conditions, any of its functions and powers under this Article to any one or more of its members, or to any ofﬁcer, body or authority in the public service
A county government is responsible, within a framework of uniform norms and standards prescribed by an Act of Parliament, for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: establishing and abolishing ofﬁces in its public service;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: appointing persons to hold or act in those ofﬁces, and conﬁrming appointments; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: exercising disciplinary control over and removing persons holding or acting in those ofﬁces

clauses.text: Clause
shall not apply to any ofﬁce or position subject to the Teachers Service Commission

A public ofﬁcer shall not be— (a) victimised or discriminated against for having performed the functions of ofﬁce in accordance with this Constitution or any other law; or (b) dismissed, removed from ofﬁce, demoted in rank or otherwise subjected to disciplinary action without due process of law. Part 3 – Teachers Service Commission
There is established the Teachers Service Commission
The functions of the Commission are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to register trained teachers;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: to recruit and employ registered teachers;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: to assign teachers employed by the Commission for service in any public school or institution;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: to promote and transfer teachers;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: to exercise disciplinary control over teachers; and

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: to terminate the employment of teachers. 89 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: The Commission shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: review the standards of education and training of persons entering the teaching service;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: review the demand for and the supply of teachers; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: advise the national government on matters relating to the teaching profession

clauses.text: National security is the protection against internal and external threats to Kenya’s territorial integrity and sovereignty, its people, their rights, freedoms, property, peace, stability and prosperity, and other national interests
The national security of Kenya shall be promoted and guaranteed in accordance with the following principles—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: national security is subject to the authority of this Constitution and Parliament;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: national security shall be pursued in compliance with the law and with the utmost respect for the rule of law, democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: in performing their functions and exercising their powers, national security organs shall respect the diverse culture of the communities within Kenya; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: recruitment by the national security organs shall reﬂect the diversity of the Kenyan people in equitable proportions

clauses.text: The national security organs are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Kenya Defence Forces;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the National Intelligence Service; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the National Police Service

clauses.text: The primary object of the national security organs and security system is to promote and guarantee national security in accordance with the principles mentioned in Article 238
In performing their functions and exercising their powers, the national security organs and every member of the national security organs shall not—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: act in a partisan manner;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: further any interest of a political party or cause; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: prejudice a political interest or political cause that is legitimate under this Constitution

clauses.text: A person shall not establish a military, paramilitary, or similar organisation that purports to promote and guarantee national security, except as provided for by this Constitution or an Act of Parliament
The national security organs are subordinate to civilian authority. 90 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for the functions, organisation and administration of the national security organs

articles.title: Establishment of the National Security Council

clauses.text: There is established a National Security Council
The Council consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the President;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Deputy President;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the Cabinet Secretary responsible for defence;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the Cabinet Secretary responsible for foreign affairs;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the Cabinet Secretary responsible for internal security;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: the Attorney-General;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: the Chief of Kenya Defence Forces;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: the Director-General of the National Intelligence Service; and

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the Inspector-General of the National Police Service

clauses.text: The Council shall exercise supervisory control over national security organs and perform any other functions prescribed by national legislation
The President shall preside at meetings of the Council
The Council shall appoint its secretary
The Council shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: integrate the domestic, foreign and military policies relating to national security in order to enable the national security organs to co-operate and function effectively; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: assess and appraise the objectives, commitments and risks to the Republic in respect of actual and potential national security capabilities

clauses.text: The Council shall report annually to Parliament on the state of the security of Kenya
The Council may, with the approval of Parliament—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: deploy national forces outside Kenya for—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: regional or international peace support operations; or (ii) other support operations; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: approve the deployment of foreign forces in Kenya. Part 2 – The Kenya Defence Forces

articles.title: Establishment of Kenya Defence Forces and Defence Council

clauses.text: There are established the Kenya Defence Forces
The Kenya Defence Forces consist of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Kenya Army;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Kenya Air Force; and 91 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the Kenya Navy

clauses.text: The Kenya Defence Forces—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: are responsible for the defence and protection of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Republic;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall assist and cooperate with other authorities in situations of emergency or disaster, and report to the National Assembly whenever deployed in such circumstances; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: may be deployed to restore peace in any part of Kenya affected by unrest or instability only with the approval of the National Assembly

clauses.text: The composition of the command of the Kenya Defence Forces shall reﬂect the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya
There is established a Defence Council
The Council consist of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Cabinet Secretary responsible for defence, who is the chairperson;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Chief of the Kenya Defence Forces;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the three commanders of the Kenya Defence forces; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the Principal Secretary in the Ministry responsible for defence

clauses.text: The Council—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is responsible for the overall policy, control, and supervision of the Kenya Defence Forces; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: performs any other functions prescribed by national legislation. Part 3 – The National Intelligence Service

clauses.text: There is established the National Intelligence Service
The National Intelligence Service—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is responsible for security intelligence and counter intelligence to enhance national security in accordance with this Constitution; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: performs any other functions prescribed by national legislation. Part 4 – The National Police Service

articles.title: Establishment of the National Police Service

clauses.text: There is established the National Police Service
The National Police Service consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Kenya Police Service; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Administration Police Service

clauses.text: The National Police Service is a national service and shall function throughout Kenya
Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to this Article. 92 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

articles.title: Objects and functions of the National Police Service

clauses.text: The National Police Service shall— (a) strive for the highest standards of professionalism and discipline among its members; (b) prevent corruption and promote and practice transparency and accountability; (c) comply with constitutional standards of human rights and fundamental freedoms; (d) train staff to the highest possible standards of competence and integrity and to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms and dignity; and (e) foster and promote relationships with the broader society

articles.title: Command of the National Police Service

clauses.text: There is established the ofﬁce of the Inspector-General of the National Police Service
The Inspector-General—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: is appointed by the President with the approval of Parliament; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall exercise independent command over the National Police Service, and perform any other functions prescribed by national legislation

clauses.text: The Kenya Police Service and the Administration Police Service shall each be headed by a Deputy Inspector-General appointed by the President in accordance with the recommendation of the National Police Service Commission

The Cabinet secretary responsible for police services may lawfully give a direction to the Inspector- General with respect to any matter of policy for the National Police Service, but no person may give a direction to the Inspector-General with respect to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the investigation of any particular offence or offences;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the enforcement of the law against any particular person or persons; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the employment, assignment, promotion, suspension or dismissal of any member of the National Police Service

clauses.text: Any direction given to the Inspector-General by the Cabinet secretary responsible for police services under clause
, or any direction given to the Inspector-General by the Director of Public Prosecutions under Article 157
, shall be in writing
The Inspector-General shall be appointed for a single four-year term, and is not eligible for re- appointment
The Inspector-General may be removed from ofﬁce by the President only on the grounds of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: serious violation of this Constitution or any other law, including a contravention of Chapter Six;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: gross misconduct whether in the performance of the ofﬁce holder’s functions or otherwise;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: physical or mental incapacity to perform the functions of ofﬁce;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: incompetence;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: bankruptcy; or

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: any other just cause

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to this Article. 93 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
There is established the National Police Service Commission
The Commission consists of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the following persons, each appointed by the President—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: a person who is qualiﬁed to be appointed as a High Court Judge; (ii) two retired senior police ofﬁcers; and (iii) three persons of integrity who have served the public with distinction;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Inspector-General of the National Police Service; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: both Deputy Inspectors-General of the National Police Service

clauses.text: The Commission shall—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: recruit and appoint persons to hold or act in ofﬁces in the service, conﬁrm appointments, and determine promotions and transfers within the National Police Service;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: observing due process, exercise disciplinary control over and remove persons holding or acting in ofﬁces within the Service; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: perform any other functions prescribed by national legislation

clauses.text: The composition of the National Police Service shall reﬂect the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya
Parliament may enact legislation establishing other police services under the supervision of the National Police Service and the command of the Inspector-General of the Service
This Chapter applies to the commissions speciﬁed in clause
and the independent ofﬁces speciﬁed in clause
, except to the extent that this Constitution provides otherwise
The commissions are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Kenya National Human Rights and Equality Commission;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the National Land Commission;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the Parliamentary Service Commission;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the Judicial Service Commission;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: the Commission on Revenue Allocation;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: the Public Service Commission;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: the Salaries and Remuneration Commission;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the Teachers Service Commission; and 94 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: the National Police Service Commission

clauses.text: The independent ofﬁces are—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Auditor-General; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Controller of Budget

articles.title: Objects, authority and funding of commissions and independent ofﬁces

clauses.text: The objects of the commissions and the independent ofﬁces are to—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: protect the sovereignty of the people;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: secure the observance by all State organs of democratic values and principles; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: promote constitutionalism

clauses.text: The commissions and the holders of independent ofﬁces—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: are subject only to this Constitution and the law; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: are independent and not subject to direction or control by any person or authority

clauses.text: Parliament shall allocate adequate funds to enable each commission and independent ofﬁce to perform its functions and the budget of each commission and independent ofﬁce shall be a separate vote

articles.title: Composition, appointment and terms of ofﬁce

clauses.text: Each commission shall consist of at least three, but not more than nine, members
The chairperson and each member of a commission, and the holder of an independent ofﬁce, shall be—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: identiﬁed and recommended for appointment in a manner prescribed by national legislation;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: approved by the National Assembly; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: appointed by the President

clauses.text: To be appointed, a person shall have the speciﬁc qualiﬁcations required by this Constitution or national legislation

Appointments to commissions and independent ofﬁces shall take into account the national values referred to in Article 10, and the principle that the composition of the commissions and ofﬁces, taken as a whole, shall reﬂect the regional and ethnic diversity of the people of Kenya
A member of a commission may serve on a part-time basis
A member of a commission, or the holder of an independent ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: unless ex ofﬁcio, shall be appointed for a single term of six years and is not eligible for re- appointment; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: unless ex ofﬁcio or part-time, shall not hold any other ofﬁce or employment for proﬁt, whether public or private

clauses.text: The remuneration and beneﬁts payable to or in respect of, a commissioner or the holder of an independent ofﬁce shall be a charge on the Consolidated Fund

The remuneration and beneﬁts payable to, or in respect of, the members of a commission or the holder of an independent ofﬁce shall not be varied to the disadvantage of that person during their respective terms of ofﬁce. 95 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
A member of a commission, or the holder of an independent ofﬁce, is not liable for anything done in good faith in the performance of a function of ofﬁce
The members of a commission shall elect a vice-chairperson from among themselves—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: at the ﬁrst sitting of the commission; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: whenever it is necessary to ﬁll a vacancy in the ofﬁce of the vice-chairperson

clauses.text: The chairperson and vice-chairperson of a commission shall not be of the same gender
There shall be a Secretary to each commission who shall be—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: appointed by the commission; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the chief executive ofﬁcer of the commission

clauses.text: A member of a commission (other than an ex ofﬁcio member), or the holder of an independent ofﬁce, may be removed from ofﬁce only for—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: serious violation of this Constitution or any other law, including a contravention of Chapter Six;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: gross misconduct, whether in the performance of the member’s or ofﬁce holder’s functions or otherwise;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: physical or mental incapacity to perform the functions of ofﬁce;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: incompetence; or

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: bankruptcy

clauses.text: A person desiring the removal of a member of a commission or of a holder of an independent ofﬁce on any ground speciﬁed in clause
may present a petition to the National Assembly setting out the alleged facts constituting that ground
The National Assembly shall consider the petition and, if it is satisﬁed that it discloses a ground under clause
, shall send the petition to the President
On receiving a petition under clause
, the President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: may suspend the member or ofﬁce holder pending the outcome of the complaint; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: shall appoint a tribunal in accordance with clause

clauses.text: The tribunal shall consist of—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a person who holds or has held ofﬁce as a judge of a superior court, who shall be the chairperson;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: at least two persons who are qualiﬁed to be appointed as High Court judges; and

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: one other member who is qualiﬁed to assess the facts in respect of the particular ground for removal

clauses.text: The tribunal shall investigate the matter expeditiously, report on the facts and make a binding recommendation to the President, who shall act in accordance with the recommendation within thirty days
A person suspended under this Article is entitled to continue to receive one-half of the remuneration and beneﬁts of the ofﬁce while suspended. 96 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
Each commission, and each holder of an independent ofﬁce—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: may conduct investigations on its own initiative or on a complaint made by a member of the public;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: has the powers necessary for conciliation, mediation and negotiation;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: shall recruit its own staff; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: may perform any functions and exercise any powers prescribed by legislation, in addition to the functions and powers conferred by this Constitution

clauses.text: A complaint to a commission or the holder of an independent ofﬁce may be made by any person entitled to institute court proceedings under Article 22
and
The following commissions and independent ofﬁces have the power to issue summons to a witness to assist for the purposes of its investigations—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Kenya National Human Rights and Equality Commission;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the Judicial Service Commission;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the National Land Commission; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the Auditor-General

articles.title: Incorporation of commissions and independent ofﬁces

clauses.text: Each commission and each independent ofﬁce— (a) is a body corporate with perpetual succession and a seal; and (b) is capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name

articles.title: Reporting by commissions and independent ofﬁces

clauses.text: As soon as practicable after the end of each ﬁnancial year, each commission, and each holder of an independent ofﬁce, shall submit a report to the President and to Parliament
At any time, the President, the National Assembly or the Senate may require a commission or holder of an independent ofﬁce to submit a report on a particular issue
Every report required from a commission or holder of an independent ofﬁce under this Article shall be published and publicised
A proposed amendment to this Constitution shall be enacted in accordance with Article 256 or 257, and approved in accordance with clause
by a referendum, if the amendment relates to any of the following matters—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the supremacy of this Constitution;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the territory of Kenya;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: the sovereignty of the people; 97 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: the national values and principles of governance referred to in Article 10

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: to

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the Bill of Rights;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: the term of ofﬁce of the President;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: the independence of the Judiciary and the commissions and independent ofﬁces to which Chapter Fifteen applies;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: the functions of Parliament;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: the objects, principles and structure of devolved government; or

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: the provisions of this Chapter

clauses.text: A proposed amendment shall be approved by a referendum under clause
if—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: at least twenty per cent of the registered voters in each of at least half of the counties vote in the referendum; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the amendment is supported by a simple majority of the citizens voting in the referendum

clauses.text: An amendment to this Constitution that does not relate to a matter speciﬁed in clause
shall be enacted either—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: by Parliament, in accordance with Article 256; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: by the people and Parliament, in accordance with Article 257

clauses.text: A Bill to amend this Constitution—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: may be introduced in either House of Parliament;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: may not address any other matter apart from consequential amendments to legislation arising from the Bill;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: shall not be called for second reading in either House within ninety days after the ﬁrst reading of the Bill in that House; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: shall have been passed by Parliament when each House of Parliament has passed the Bill, in both its second and third readings, by not less than two-thirds of all the members of that House

clauses.text: Parliament shall publicise any Bill to amend this Constitution, and facilitate public discussion about the Bill
After Parliament passes a Bill to amend this Constitution, the Speakers of the two Houses of Parliament shall jointly submit to the President—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the Bill, for assent and publication; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a certiﬁcate that the Bill has been passed by Parliament in accordance with this Article

clauses.text: Subject to clause
, the President shall assent to the Bill and cause it to be published within thirty days after the Bill is enacted by Parliament
If a Bill to amend this Constitution proposes an amendment relating to a matter speciﬁed in Article 255

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the President shall, before assenting to the Bill, request the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission to conduct, within ninety days, a national referendum for approval of the Bill; and 98 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: within thirty days after the chairperson of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission has certiﬁed to the President that the Bill has been approved in accordance with Article 255

clauses.text: , the President shall assent to the Bill and cause it to be published
An amendment to this Constitution may be proposed by a popular initiative signed by at least one million registered voters
A popular initiative for an amendment to this Constitution may be in the form of a general suggestion or a formulated draft Bill
If a popular initiative is in the form of a general suggestion, the promoters of that popular initiative shall formulate it into a draft Bill

The promoters of a popular initiative shall deliver the draft Bill and the supporting signatures to the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission, which shall verify that the initiative is supported by at least one million registered voters

If the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission is satisﬁed that the initiative meets the requirements of this Article, the Commission shall submit the draft Bill to each county assembly for consideration within three months after the date it was submitted by the Commission

If a county assembly approves the draft Bill within three months after the date it was submitted by the Commission, the speaker of the county assembly shall deliver a copy of the draft Bill jointly to the Speakers of the two Houses of Parliament, with a certiﬁcate that the county assembly has approved it
If a draft Bill has been approved by a majority of the county assemblies, it shall be introduced in Parliament without delay
A Bill under this Article is passed by Parliament if supported by a majority of the members of each House
If Parliament passes the Bill, it shall be submitted to the President for assent in accordance with Article 256
and
If either House of Parliament fails to pass the Bill, or the Bill relates to a matter speciﬁed in Article 255
, the proposed amendment shall be submitted to the people in a referendum
Article 255
applies, with any necessary modiﬁcations, to a referendum under clause
Every person has the right to institute court proceedings, claiming that this Constitution has been contravened, or is threatened with contravention
In addition to a person acting in their own interest, court proceedings under clause
may be instituted by—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a person acting on behalf of another person who cannot act in their own name;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a person acting as a member of, or in the interest of, a group or class of persons;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a person acting in the public interest; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: an association acting in the interest of one or more of its members. 99 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: This Constitution shall be interpreted in a manner that—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: promotes its purposes, values and principles;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: advances the rule of law, and the human rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: permits the development of the law; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: contributes to good governance

clauses.text: If there is a conﬂict between different language versions of this Constitution, the English language version prevails
Every provision of this Constitution shall be construed according to the doctrine of interpretation that the law is always speaking and, therefore, among other things—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a function or power conferred by this Constitution on an ofﬁce may be performed or exercised as occasion requires, by the person holding the ofﬁce;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any reference in this Constitution to a State or other public ofﬁce or ofﬁcer, or a person holding such an ofﬁce, includes a reference to the person acting in or otherwise performing the functions of the ofﬁce at any particular time;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: a reference in this Constitution to an ofﬁce, State organ or locality named in this Constitution shall be read with any formal alteration necessary to make it applicable in the circumstances; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: a reference in this Constitution to an ofﬁce, body or organisation is, if the ofﬁce, body or organisation has ceased to exist, a reference to its successor or to the equivalent ofﬁce, body or organisation

clauses.text: In this Constitution, unless the context otherwise requires—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: if a word or expression is deﬁned in this Constitution, any grammatical variation or cognate expression of the word or expression has a corresponding meaning, read with the changes required by the context; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: the word "includes" means "includes, but is not limited to"

clauses.text: In calculating time between two events for any purpose under this Constitution, if the time is expressed—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: as days, the day on which the ﬁrst event occurs shall be excluded, and the day by which the last event may occur shall be included;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: as months, the time period ends at the beginning of the day in the relevant month—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: that has the same number as the date on which the period began, if that month has a corresponding date; or (ii) that is the last day of that month, in any other case; or

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: as years, the period of time ends at the beginning of the date of the relevant year that corresponds to the date on which the period began

clauses.text: If a period of time prescribed by this Constitution for any purpose is six days or less, Sundays and public holidays shall not count when calculating the time

If, in any particular circumstances, the period of time prescribed by this Constitution ends on a Sunday or a public holiday, the period extends to the ﬁrst subsequent day that is not a Sunday or public holiday. 100 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
If a particular time is not prescribed by this Constitution for performing a required act, the act shall be done without unreasonable delay, and as often as occasion arises

If any person or State organ has authority under this Constitution to extend a period of time prescribed by this Constitution, the authority may be exercised either before or after the end of the period, unless a contrary intention is expressly speciﬁed in the provision conferring the authority

Except to the extent that this Constitution provides otherwise, if a person has vacated an ofﬁce established under this Constitution, the person may, if qualiﬁed, again be appointed, elected or otherwise selected to hold the ofﬁce in accordance with this Constitution

If a function or power conferred on a person under this Constitution is exercisable by the person only on the advice or recommendation, with the approval or consent of, or on consultation with, another person, the function may be performed or the power exercised only on that advice, recommendation, with that approval or consent, or after that consultation, except to the extent that this Constitution provides otherwise

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: ; "land" includes— 101 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: the surface of the earth and the subsurface rock;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any body of water on or under the surface;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: marine waters in the territorial sea and exclusive economic zone;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: natural resources completely contained on or under the surface; and

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: the air space above the surface; "legislation" includes—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: an Act of Parliament, or a law made under authority conferred by an Act of Parliament; or

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a law made by an assembly of a county government, or under authority conferred by such a law; "loan" includes any form of borrowing, lending or deferred payment in respect of which money from a public fund may be used, or is required to be used, for payment or repayment; "marginalised community" means—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: a community that, because of its relatively small population or for any other reason, has been unable to fully participate in the integrated social and economic life of Kenya as a whole;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: a traditional community that, out of a need or desire to preserve its unique culture and identity from assimilation, has remained outside the integrated social and economic life of Kenya as a whole;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: an indigenous community that has retained and maintained a traditional lifestyle and livelihood based on a hunter or gatherer economy; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: pastoral persons and communities, whether they are—

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: nomadic; or (ii) a settled community that, because of its relative geographic isolation, has experienced only marginal participation in the integrated social and economic life of Kenya as a whole; "marginalised group" means a group of people who, because of laws or practices before, on, or after the effective date, were or are disadvantaged by discrimination on one or more of the grounds in Article 27

clauses.text: ; "national legislation" means an Act of Parliament, or a law made under authority conferred by an Act of Parliament; "natural resources" means the physical non-human factors and components, whether renewable or non- renewable, including—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: sunlight;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: surface and groundwater;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: forests, biodiversity and genetic resources; and

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: rocks, minerals, fossil fuels and other sources of energy; "older member of society" means a person who has attained the age of sixty years; "person" includes a company, association or other body of persons whether incorporated or unincorporated; "political party" means an association contemplated in Part 3 of Chapter Seven; "property" includes any vested or contingent right to, or interest in or arising from—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: land, or permanent ﬁxtures on, or improvements to, land;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: goods or personal property; 102 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: intellectual property; or

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: money, choses in action or negotiable instruments; "public ofﬁcer" means—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: any State ofﬁcer; or 103 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: any person, other that a State Ofﬁcer, who holds a public ofﬁce; "public ofﬁce" means an ofﬁce in the national government, a county government or the public service, if the remuneration and beneﬁts of the ofﬁce are payable directly from the Consolidated Fund or directly out of money provided by Parliament; "public service" means the collectivity of all individuals, other than State ofﬁcers, performing a function within a State organ; "Republic" means the Republic of Kenya; "State", when used as a noun, means the collectivity of ofﬁces, organs and other entities comprising the government of the Republic under this Constitution; "State ofﬁce" means any of the following ofﬁces—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: President;

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: Deputy President;

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: Cabinet Secretary;

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: Member of Parliament;

subClauses.label: e
subClauses.text: Judges and Magistrates;

subClauses.label: f
subClauses.text: member of a commission to which Chapter Fifteen applies;

subClauses.label: g
subClauses.text: holder of an independent ofﬁce to which Chapter Fifteen applies;

subClauses.label: h
subClauses.text: member of a county assembly, governor or deputy governor of a county, or other member of the executive committee of a county government;

subClauses.label: i
subClauses.text: Attorney-General;

subClauses.label: j
subClauses.text: Director of Public Prosecutions;

subClauses.label: k
subClauses.text: Secretary to the Cabinet;

subClauses.label: l
subClauses.text: Principal Secretary;

subClauses.label: m
subClauses.text: Chief of the Kenya Defence Forces;

subClauses.label: n
subClauses.text: commander of a service of the Kenya Defence Forces;

subClauses.label: o
subClauses.text: Director-General of the National Intelligence Service;

subClauses.label: p
subClauses.text: Inspector-General, and the Deputy Inspectors-General, of the National Police Service; or

subClauses.label: q
subClauses.text: an ofﬁce established and designated as a State ofﬁce by national legislation; "State ofﬁcer" means a person holding a State ofﬁce; "State organ" means a commission, ofﬁce, agency or other body established under this Constitution; "writing" includes printing, photography, lithography, typewriting, Braille, and any other means of representing or reproducing words in a visible form; and "youth" means the collectivity of all individuals in the Republic who—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: have attained the age of eighteen years; but

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: have not attained the age of thirty-ﬁve years. 104 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

clauses.text: Parliament shall enact any legislation required by this Constitution to be enacted to govern a particular matter within the period speciﬁed in the Fifth Schedule, commencing on the effective date
Despite clause

, the National Assembly may, by resolution supported by the votes of at least two- thirds of all the members of the National Assembly, extend the period prescribed in respect of any particular matter under clause
, by a period not exceeding one year
The power of the National Assembly contemplated under clause
, may be exercised—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: only once in respect of any particular matter; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: only in exceptional circumstances to be certiﬁed by the Speaker of the National Assembly

clauses.text: For the purposes of clause

, the Attorney-General, in consultation with the Commission for the Implementation of the Constitution, shall prepare the relevant Bills for tabling before Parliament, as soon as reasonably practicable, to enable Parliament to enact the legislation within the period speciﬁed
If Parliament fails to enact any particular legislation within the speciﬁed time, any person may petition the High Court on the matter
The High Court in determining a petition under clause
may—

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: make a declaratory order on the matter; and

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: transmit an order directing Parliament and the Attorney-General to take steps to ensure that the required legislation is enacted, within the period speciﬁed in the order, and to report the progress to the Chief Justice

clauses.text: If Parliament fails to enact legislation in accordance with an order under clause

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: , the Chief Justice shall advise the President to dissolve Parliament and the President shall dissolve Parliament

clauses.text: If Parliament has been dissolved under clause
, the new Parliament shall enact the required legislation within the periods speciﬁed in the Fifth Schedule beginning with the date of commencement of the term of the new Parliament
If the new Parliament fails to enact legislation in accordance with clause
, the provisions of clauses
to
shall apply afresh
The transitional and consequential provisions set out in the Sixth Schedule shall take effect on the effective date

This Constitution shall come into force on its promulgation by the President or on the expiry of a period of fourteen days from the date of the publication in the Gazette of the ﬁnal result of the referendum ratifying this Constitution, whichever is the earlier. 105 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
106 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: a
subClauses.text: The National Flag 108 Constitution of Kenya Kenya Note - All dimensions given do not necessarily represent any particular measurement and are merely proportional. Description— Three major strips of equal width coloured from top to bottom black, red and green and separated by narrow white strips, with a symmetrical shield and white spears superimposed centrally. 109 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: b
subClauses.text: The National Anthem 1 1 Ee Mungu nguvu yetu Ilete baraka kwetu O God of all creation Bless this our land and nation Haki iwe ngao na mlinzi Natukae na undugu Justice be our shield and defender May we dwell in unity Amani na uhuru Raha tupate na ustawi Peace and liberty Plenty be found within our borders 2 2 110 Constitution of Kenya Kenya Amkeni ndugu zetu Tufanye sote bidii Let one and all arise With hearts both strong and true Nasi tujitoe kwa nguvu Nchi yetu ya Kenya, Service be our earnest endeavour, And our Homeland of Kenya Tunayoipenda Tuwe tayari kuilinda. Heritage of splendour, Firm may we stand to defend. 3 3 Natujenge taifa letu Ee, ndio wajibu wetu Let all with one accord In common bond united, Kenya istahili heshima Tuungane mikono Build this our nation together And the glory of Kenya Pamoja kazini Kila siku tuwe na shukrani. The fruit of our labour Fill every heart with thanksgiving. 111 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

subClauses.label: c
subClauses.text: The Coat of Arms

subClauses.label: d
subClauses.text: The Public Seal 112 Constitution of Kenya Kenya THIRD SCHEDULE NATIONAL OATHS AND AFFIRMATIONS Article 74, Article 141

clauses.text: , Article 148
and Article 152

. OATH OR SOLEMN AFFIRMATION OF ALLEGIANCE OF THE PRESIDENT/ACTING PRESIDENT AND THE DEPUTY PRESIDENT I, ………..........................................……, in full realisation of the high calling I assume as President/Acting President/ Deputy President of the Republic of Kenya, do swear/solemnly afﬁrm that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to the Republic of Kenya; that I will obey, preserve, protect and defend this Constitution of Kenya, as by law established, and all other laws of the Republic; and that I will protect and uphold the sovereignty, integrity and dignity of the people of Kenya. (In the case of an oath — So help me God.) OATH OR SOLEMN AFFIRMATION OF DUE EXECUTION OF OFFICE FOR THE PRESIDENT/ACTING PRESIDENT I, ………................................................………, swear/solemnly afﬁrm that I will truly and diligently serve the people and the Republic of Kenya in the ofﬁce of the President/ Acting President of the Republic of Kenya; that I will diligently discharge my duties and perform my functions in the Ofﬁce of President/Acting President of the Republic of Kenya; and I will do justice to all in accordance with this Constitution, as by law established, and the laws of Kenya, without fear, favour, affection or ill- will. (In the case of an oath— So help me God.) OATH OR SOLEMN AFFIRMATION OF DUE EXECUTION OF OFFICE FOR THE DEPUTY PRESIDENT I, …………..............................…………, do swear/solemnly afﬁrm that I will always truly and diligently serve the people and the Republic of Kenya in the ofﬁce of the Deputy President of the Republic of Kenya; that I will diligently discharge my duties and perform my functions in the said ofﬁce, to the best of my judgment; that I will at all times, when so required, faithfully and truly give my counsel and advice to the President of the Republic of Kenya; that I will do justice to all without fear, favour, affection or ill-will; and that I will not directly or indirectly reveal such matters as shall come to my knowledge in the discharge of my duties and committed to my secrecy. (In the case of an oath— So help me God.) 113 Constitution of Kenya Kenya OATH OR SOLEMN AFFIRMATION OF DUE EXECUTION OF OFFICE FOR A CABINET SECRETARY I, …….......................................……………, being appointed a Cabinet Secretary of Kenya, do swear/solemnly afﬁrm that I will at all times be faithful to the Republic of Kenya; that I will obey, respect and uphold this Constitution of Kenya and all other laws of the Republic; that I will well and truly serve the people and the Republic of Kenya in the Ofﬁce of a Cabinet Secretary; that I undertake to hold my ofﬁce as Cabinet Secretary with honour and dignity; that I will be a true and faithful counsellor to the President for the good management of the public affairs of the Republic of Kenya; that I will not divulge directly or indirectly such matters as shall come to my knowledge in the discharge of my duties and committed to my secrecy except as may be required for the due discharge of my duties as Cabinet Secretary; and that I will perform the functions of my ofﬁce conscientiously and to the best of my ability. (In the case of an oath— So help me God.) OATH OR SOLEMN AFFIRMATION OF DUE EXECUTION OF OFFICE FOR SECRETARY TO THE CABINET/ A PRINCIPAL SECRETARY I, ……...................................………………, being called on to exercise the functions of Secretary to the Cabinet / a Principal Secretary, do swear/solemnly afﬁrm that, except with the authority of the President, I will not directly or indirectly reveal the nature or contents of any business, proceedings or document of the Cabinet committed to my secrecy, except as may be required for the due discharge of my duties as Secretary to the Cabinet /such Principal Secretary. (In the case of an oath— So help me God.) OATHS FOR THE CHIEF JUSTICE/PRESIDENT OF THE SUPREME COURT, JUDGES OF THE SUPREME COURT, JUDGES OF THE COURT OF APPEAL AND JUDGES OF THE HIGH COURT I, ……………......................................………, (The Chief Justice/President of the Supreme Court, a judge of the Supreme Court, a judge of the Court of Appeal, a judge of the High Court) do (swear in the name of the Almighty God)/(solemnly afﬁrm) to diligently serve the people and the Republic of Kenya and to impartially do Justice in accordance with this Constitution as by law established, and the laws and customs of the Republic, without any fear, favour, bias, affection, ill-will, prejudice or any political, religious or other inﬂuence. In the exercise of the judicial functions entrusted to me, I will at all times, and to the best of my knowledge and ability, protect, administer and defend this Constitution with a view to upholding the dignity and the respect for the judiciary and the judicial system of Kenya and promoting fairness, independence, competence and integrity within it. (So help me God.) OATH /AFFIRMATION OF MEMBER OF PARLIAMENT (SENATE/ NATIONAL ASSEMBLY) I,………...................................……………, having been elected a member of the Senate/National Assembly do swear (in the name of the Almighty God) (solemnly afﬁrm) that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the People and the Republic of Kenya; that I will obey, respect, uphold, preserve, protect and defend this Constitution of the Republic of Kenya; and that I will faithfully and conscientiously discharge the duties of a member of Parliament. (So help me God.) *OATH FOR SPEAKER/DEPUTY SPEAKER OF THE SENATE/NATIONAL ASSEMBLY 114 Constitution of Kenya Kenya I, ...........................................……………, having been elected as Speaker/ Deputy Speaker of the Senate/ National Assembly do swear (in the name of the Almighty God) (solemnly afﬁrm) that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the people and the Republic of Kenya; that I will faithfully and conscientiously discharge my duties as Speaker/Deputy Speaker of the Senate/National Assembly; that I will obey, respect, uphold, preserve, protect and defend this Constitution of the Republic of Kenya; and that I will do right to all manner of persons in accordance with this Constitution of Kenya and the laws and conventions of Parliament without fear or favour, affection or ill will. (So help me God.) FOURTH SCHEDULE DISTRIBUTION OF FUNCTIONS BETWEEN THE NATIONAL GOVERNMENT AND THE COUNTY GOVERNMENTS Article 185
, Article 186
and Article 187
DISTRIBUTION OF FUNCTIONS BETWEEN THE NATIONAL GOVERNMENT AND THE COUNTY GOVERNMENTS Part 1 – NATIONAL GOVERNMENT
(a) the setting of standards of recruitment, training of police and use of police services; (b) criminal law; and (c) correctional services

articles.title: Monetary policy, currency, banking (including central banking), the incorporation and regulation of

clauses.text: banking, insurance and ﬁnancial corporations

articles.title: Universities, tertiary educational institutions and other institutions of research and higher learning and

clauses.text: primary schools, special education, secondary schools and special education institutions

articles.title: Promotion of sports and sports education

clauses.text: 115 Constitution of Kenya Kenya

articles.title: Transport and communications, including, in particular—

clauses.text: (a) road trafﬁc; (b) the construction and operation of national trunk roads; (c) standards for the construction and maintenance of other roads by counties; (d) railways; (e) pipelines; (f) marine navigation; (g) civil aviation; (h) space travel; (i) postal services; (j) telecommunications; and (k) radio and television broadcasting

articles.title: Protection of the environment and natural resources with a view to establishing a durable and sustainable

clauses.text: system of development, including, in particular— (a) ﬁshing, hunting and gathering; (b) protection of animals and wildlife; (c) water protection, securing sufﬁcient residual water, hydraulic engineering and the safety of dams; and (d) energy policy
116 Constitution of Kenya Kenya Part 2 – COUNTY GOVERNMENTS The functions and powers of the county are—
(a) crop and animal husbandry; (b) livestock sale yards; (c) county abattoirs; (d) plant and animal disease control; and (e) ﬁsheries

articles.title: County health services, including, in particular—

clauses.text: (a) county health facilities and pharmacies; (b) ambulance services; (c) promotion of primary health care; (d) licensing and control of undertakings that sell food to the public; (e) veterinary services (excluding regulation of the profession); (f) cemeteries, funeral parlours and crematoria; and (g) refuse removal, refuse dumps and solid waste disposal

articles.title: Cultural activities, public entertainment and public amenities, including—

clauses.text: (a) betting, casinos and other forms of gambling; (b) racing; (c) liquor licensing; (d) cinemas; (e) video shows and hiring; (f) libraries; (g) museums; (h) sports and cultural activities and facilities; and (i) county parks, beaches and recreation facilities

(a) county roads; (b) street lighting; (c) trafﬁc and parking; (d) public road transport; and (e) ferries and harbours, excluding the regulation of international and national shipping and matters related thereto. 117 Constitution of Kenya Kenya
